title: work-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall-set-start-soon
story: The much-anticipated hall has been in the pipeline for several years and plans for the expansion were lodged with East Lothian Council more than two years ago.The local authority says that contracts for the work are expected to be awarded this month, with contractors expected to start on site in September.The new hall will allow the centre to offer more activities and a wider range of sports than ever before, including basketball, badminton, tennis and football.It will also allow centre regulars such as East Lothian Gymnastics Association the chance to train with a proper run-up to their apparatus.The new hall, which will be an extension to the main building, will measure  metres by  metres and also includes storage areas.There will be a new lobby created to link the hall to the cafe area of the main centre building and it will provide capacity for more classes to be held in the centre.It is being built to the west of the current building, with plans to move the childrenrsquos play area, re-siting it beside the new hall, in an area which will be better positioned for parents to keep an eye on youngsters.A report to the council revealed there had been a delay on the work as the ldquotechnical specs were revised to bring it within budget.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe main elements of our investment at Port Seton Community Centre to provide a new sports hall with provision for gymnastics remains unchanged.ldquoIn order to secure best value and deliver the project within budget, we have revisited the technical specications for the project.ldquoWe now anticipate awarding the contract for works in late July with contractors starting on site in September.ldquoWe are working with the centrersquos management group to keep them involved as the project progresses.

title: prestonpans-schools-pupils-aiming-get-involved-community
story: St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School sent P representatives Olivia Lees, Ciaran Kelly, Fraser Graham, and Daniel McCabe, all , to speak to Prestonpans Community Council about their work and the potential involvement of much younger participants.The school was recently successful in achieving its UNICEF Rights Respecting School gold award, which means that it had proved that it incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child into the school through both teaching and actions.It now aims to take this further and bring this ethos into the surrounding community.The children were given the chance of addressing the meeting, which included ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and Neil Gilbert, to ask questions and discuss the best ways to engage young people with what is going on in the community and to ensure their input is noted.The children asked about the plans for the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station and whether more activities for young people such as Rainbows and Scouts could be introduced to the areaWhen addressing the councillors and community councillors, Daniel, a house captain from St Gabrielrsquos, said: ldquoItrsquos important for us at this stage to know what our future is going to hold, and to try and make a dference when and where we can.ldquoTo be involved in the community council in some way would be fantastic, as it would give us comfort to know that the community is being taken care of, as well as what decisions were being made that might affect us.It was decided that the community council would send the agenda for each meeting to the school a few days before the meeting took place so that the children could see it and comment on any issues being raised.The community council said in a statement: ldquoWe would like to thank the four fantastic pupils from St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who attended the community council.ldquoIt was so refreshing to have such polite and knowledgeable young people along to one of our meetings to share their opinions and views on our agenda topics and ask the questions they feel most relevant to their lives.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them along to future meetings and collaborating with them on the issues that affect all of us living in Prestonpans.

title: musselburgh-neighbours-scoop-30-000-thanks-postcode
story: The Stoneyhill Crescent neighbours netted the windfall when EH TD was announced as a winner with Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery on Tuesday.The prize was won as part of a special summer campaign where a lucky postcode will be announced as a winner of the poundK prize every day. All the players in that postcode then pick up a cheque worth poundK for every ticket that they play with.The duo were the only people playing with the winning postcode, and chose to remain anonymous, but had any of their neighbours been playing then they too would have picked up a cheque for pound,.Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery ambassador Matt Johnson sent his congratulations, saying: ldquoI couldnrsquot be more thrilled for the lucky Musselburgh pair picking up a prize today.ldquoI was lucky enough to spend the day in the town and got to enjoy an ice cream from the famous Lucarsquos, as well as visit Newhailes House, which is just minutes along the road from our winners and run by National Trust for Scotland - an organisation thatrsquos been awarded pound, in funding raised by players.ldquoWith Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery good causes win too and itrsquos great to see that, no matter where you go in the country, yoursquore never far from an organisation thatrsquos benefitted from the support of our players.With a minimum of  per cent from ticket sales going directly to charities, players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery have raised more than pound million to date for thousands of projects across Great Britain and internationally.This draw was promoted on behalf of Depaul which has received over pound. million thanks to player support.This funding is enabling the charity to tackle both the immediate and long-term effects of homelessness, helping it provide safe and stable futures for people who get left behind by society.For more information on Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery visit www.postcodelottery or Facebook and Twitter.

title: stars-set-arrive-fringe-sea
story: Newsnightrsquos Kirsty Wark is among the first big names to appear as she discuss her new novel Fred MacAulay light ups the stage with his comedy and dance music pioneers Inner City will get the Simpson  Marwick Spiegeltent at the harbour shaking tomorrow evening.There is something for everyone during the August - extravaganza, from jazz performed in the North Berwick Fry and rock-pooling on the stunning North Berwick coast, to a chance to dance to pop sensation Be Charlotte and chat about all things Scottish with author Pete Irvine.The film segment of the festival welcomes local film Connect, along with Netflix hit Outlaw King, introduced by producer Danny McGrath, whereas those with an eye and ear for comedy can indulge in festival favourites Simon Evans, Janey Godley, Jamie MacDonald, Reginald D Hunter and last yearrsquos Edinburgh Comedy Award nominee Glenn Moore.Crime novel obsessives will have the opportunity to see Ian Rankin, as well as Alexander McCall Smith talking with Lord David Steel, Val McDermid with Sir Menzies Campbell, and appearances from John Niven, Malachy Tallack, Peter Irvine and Dr David Hetherington.There will also be talks presented by Speaker Buzz from inspirational women Mollie Hughes, Sara Sheridan, Jojo Fraser and Cal Major.All of this as well as singers Alexander OrsquoNeal and Eddi Reader, dance music act Groove Armada, rockers Idlewild, former Prime Minister Gordon Brown and famed wildle camera man Doug Allan makes this festival impossible to miss.Niall Middleton, festival co-ordinator, said: ldquoThe Spiegeltents are going up, the volunteers are gathering, and the performers are heading to North Berwick for  days of great entertainment. ldquoA great big thank you to all our sponsors and funding bodies for making this all possible.A host of local residents are also performing.For tickets, go to www.fringe bythesea

title: student-play-key-role-developing-cycling-scotland
story: Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Louie Doig is one of nine who will represent the voice of young people in the sport.The , which is led by the sportrsquos governing body Scottish Cycling, aims to help influence and shape the future of Cycling in Scotland.It met for the first time at Scottish Cyclingrsquos headquarters at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow last month.Louie, who is about to start a degree in Sports Science at Glasgow University, has been part of Edinburgh Road Club since Summer , with his most recent success being a win in the Peebles CC Road Race earlier this year.He believes it is vital that Scottish Cycling has a  for young people to express their views.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to the opportunity of working with my fellow members to develop a range of new projects to get more people cycling across Scotland.The  will be engaged in projects across the organisation ndash from regional development to events, and coaching and education.Craig Burn, Scottish Cycling CEO, said: ldquoI look forward to seeing the positive impact their dedication and passion for cycling in Scotland has.

title: fringe-sea-gullane-games-innerwick-flower-show-among-attractions-weekend
story: The Courierhas put together a list of five of the top things to do between this evening and over the weekend.Whether it is football or flowers, horses or celebrities ormuch more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Fringe by the SeaThe great and good of art, comedy and music are set to light up the countyrsquos coastline as North Berwickrsquos Fringe by the Sea festival launches today .Tonight, at pm, there is a chance to hear Newsnights Kirsty Wark discuss her new novel in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent.Later that evening, at pm, it is the turn of Fred MacAulay.The comedian and radio presenter will light up the stage with his comedy in the same venue.Meanwhile, in the towns community centre, NB Movies is showing Neither Wolf Nor Dog from pm.Tomorrow , former Masterchef winner, food writer and novelist Sue Lawrence visits the towns library.From pm, she will discuss her new novel Down to the Sea, which is set in Newhaven.Comedian Reginald D Hunter performs in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm while there is live music from The Cuban Brothers from pm in the same venue.Sunday brings Edinburgh-based author, speaker, blogger and podcaster JoJo Fraser to the Lighthouse Spiegeltent from pm.Then, at pm in the same venue, DJ Monski Mouse will be playing some hits specially for the under-fives and parents carers.American RB singer-songwriter Alexander ONeal will be in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm.There is plenty more on offer from todaythrough to August .For tickets, go to www.fringebythesea. Gullane GamesTHE curtain comes down on another memorable Gullane Games.This eveningfeatures a quiz night in the village hall for over-s.Tickets are pound for a team of four and available from gullanegames@outlookThe main event is Gullane Games Day itself tomorrow , plus parade.The parade under way at the childrenrsquos course at .pm.Fancy dress is optional and the theme of the parade is lsquoOur Natural Environmentrsquo.Prizes will be awarded for the best costume to age categories P and under, and P and above.The first race begins at .pm, while a tea tent, face painting, beat the goalie, assault course and tug of war are also on offer.Throughout the week, shops will be displaying lsquodeliberate mistakesrsquo in their windows for children to spot entry forms for the competition are available from the pharmacy on the opening day of the games.. Innerwick Flower ShowTHE th annual Innerwick Flower Show takes place on Saturday and promises a fun family day out.Flower displays, home baking, crafts and stalls of all kinds are on offer.Residents have been working hard to prepare their entries for a iety of competitions.Keen gardeners, crafters and bakers have been working around the clock to finesse their pieces.They will be entering competitions such as best sunflower, best bouquet, best Victoria sponge and largest cabbage, with the judges ready to make their decisions.Awards will be presented by Sheila Knox, whose late father Bob Denholm was a loyal supporter of the show and has an award named after him.Doors for the event open at pm for a .pm start.. Friday Night at the RacesMUSSELBURGH Racecourse is prepared for a busy summer spell with the first of four August meetings today .Friday Night at the Races is a firm favourite with the after-work crowd who want to let off steam after a hard week and ease into weekend downtime.Doors open at pm, which gives plenty of time ahead of the first race of the evening.With seven competitive flat races and prize money of more than pound,, the action gets underway at .pm with the Irish Stallion Farms EBF Median Auction Novice Stakes over seven furlongs.Feature race of the evening is the pound, Geoghegans sprint handicap over five furlongs at .pm.After the last race at .pm, racecourse favourites FunkWagen get the party started with summer tunes on the Loretto Lawn.For more information and to purchase tickets visit www.musselburgh-racecourse . FootballTHE new season got under way in East Lothian last Saturday and there are three home games to choose from on Saturday when you can go along and cheer on your local team.Musselburgh Athletic, Tranent and Preston Athletic are all at home, with kick-off at .pm at each game.Premier Division Musselburgh welcome Sauchie to East Lothian, with both teams still looking to get their first wins of the season.Musselburgh lost out to Dunbar, who scored a late winner ,last weekend.Meanwhile, Tranent, who have won one and drawn one of their opening two games, will play host to Jeanfield Swts.Finally, Preston Athletic welcome Stirling University and will be looking to build on their midweek - demolition of Tweedmouth Rangers.

title: ten-schools-new-headteachers---child-39-s-one
story: Building work is continuing at Letham Mains Primary School, Haddington, with Bruce Murray appointed the schoolrsquos first headteacher.Letham Mains Primary School pupils are currently being hosted within Haddington Primary School.Mr Murray, previously headteacher at Windygoul Primary School, is one of a number of new headteachers appointed.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, the local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoItrsquos great that our teachers and senior leaders choose to stay in our authority area and we can retain their experience and enthusiasm within our schools.ldquoIrsquom pleased to welcome new headteachers to our schools and look forward to further positive recruitment campaigns to fill the vacancies we have available.

title: rnli-crew-welcome-french-visitors
story: Keen swimmers Charlotte Bapao and Amelie Bobes have swapped the French village of Serres-Castet,  kilometres from Biarritz on Francersquos west coast, for a trip to Scotland.The exchange has come through Haddington and District Amateur Swimming Club, with the two youngsters visiting the RNLI to see the work that they do and to climb aboard the inshore leboat.Charlotte and Amelie, both , are members of the villagersquos swimming club, with exchange trips between the two swimming clubs dating back more than  years.More than  youngsters have enjoyed a -day stay with families throughout the county.Charlotte and Amelie have been staying with crew member Iain McDougall and family.A spokeswoman for Dunbar RNLI said: ldquoHis children, Jack, Katie and Robbie, joined the girls as fellow crew member Becs Miller told them all about the importance of staying safe in the water, while showing them the equipment we use and how our D-class inshore leboat helps us save lives at sea.

title: roadworks-close-one-main-routes-musselburgh
story: The B from Monktonhall Place to Musselburgh Services roundabout closes from midnight on Monday and is due to run until the end of August .The council said it has held extensive discussions with the contractor GTC, working on behalf of Persimmon Homes, to agree a -hour work programme that coordinates gas and power works to minimise disruption in the area.A council spokesperson said: "This closure is essential to put in place the utilities infrastructure required to support major new developments in the area."The contractor originally applied for a three week closure period."However our priority is to minimise disruption to residents and drivers so we have negotiated a -hour work programme that coordinates utility services to ensure this work is completed quickly and ahead of the schools ing."Diversion signs will be in place throughout the works. A copy of the road closure noticeis available online from www.tellmescotland.gov.ukFollowing discussions, Prentice Coaches has confirmed that it will operate the  service as normal to Tesco, then operate via Eskview Terrace, Monktonhall Terrace, Mayfield Crescent, Stoneybank Crescent, Whitehill Farm Road, QMU, Clayknowes Road to the Fort Kinnaird, the Wisp and Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.The council will arrange a free shuttle bus from Old Craighall to the ERI along the  service route. Passengers wanting to travel to Musselburgh from Old Craighall, Millerhill and Newton Village can use the shuttle service to the ERI and transfer to the  service ERI-Musselburgh. The shuttle bus will run as per the existing  timetable.Further work is planned from the service area roundabout on the B south west to the Midlothian boundary.Discussions are still ongoing with the contractor to agree traffic management for this section.Planning permission in principle was granted for a mixed use development at Old Craighall including , homes, a primary school, business space, community facilities, public parks and playing fields, an innovation hub for business and for other employment land.A separate application, also by Persimmon Homes, for detailed planning permission for  houses and  flats on the Old Craighall site was also approved at the meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos Planning Committee earlier this year.The application for the mixed use development at Old Craighall, as allocated in the Local Development Plan, was submitted following community consultation including a public event at The Brunton, Musselburgh.The total site is . hectares and refers to land around Queen Margaret Universityand Musselburgh railway station and to the north and south of the A.The plans include improvements to the junction off the A at QMU as well as the creation of pedestrian and cycle routes including the councilrsquos Segregated Active Travel Corridor.The Innovation Hub at QMT is part of the multi-million pound Edinburgh  South East Scotland City Region Deal, which will contribute to the joint development between East Lothian Council and QMU.The hub will facilitate an expansion of the universityrsquos existing Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation and will also provide flexible commercial space for small and medium sized businesses in the food and drink sector.Council officers had recommended granting of permission in principle for the two applications with conditions and a Section  agreement to fund transport infrastructure improvements, contributions for the new primary school and for secondary education provision and for community pitches.Planning committee members unanimously agreed to approve both applications.The permission granted for the first phase of housing on the Old Craighall site includes  affordable units.

title: objections-lodged-plans-rocket-engine-test-site
story: Scottish space company Skyrora has applied to East Lothian Council to occupy the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station coal handling plant for five years to build a temporary equipment test site.Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council hosted an event with representatives from Skyrora in attendance and raised some concerns that they had gathered both from within the community council and from the locals.Among the issues raised related to the results of the noise assessment that Skyrora had conducted on the surrounding area to measure the impact of the engine tests.The community council felt that not enough distinction was made between familiar noise and unfamiliar noise, with particular reference to the finding that bird song was the prevailing noise in the area.Also mentioned was the potential site traffic travelling on the B, past Cockenzie Primary School and therefore becoming disruptive, and lastly, that the security fencing planned for the site would not be high enough to guarantee that it will prevent unlawful access. Bryan Hickman, chairman of the community council, said: ldquoThe community council thank the representatives of Skyrora for meeting the community.ldquoMany questions were raised including the objections submitted by the community council and the others from the floor. In my opinion, the answers to some of the points raised were not clear or consistent with the planning documents submitted.ldquoThe consensus was that this development is not suitable for a site situated close to residential areas, schools and busy roads.Derek Harris, business operations manager at Skyrora, said: ldquoSuch is our commitment to keeping the local community up to speed on plans and taking their views into account, this was our fourth meeting in the town.ldquoThe test site offers East Lothian the opportunity to play an invaluable role in the infrastructure to support Scotlandrsquos existing space ambitions and inspire the next generation in the town to a career in STEM [science, technology, engineering, mathematics] while bringing a raft of economic opportunities to the town.Skyrora recently successfully tested their first D-printed commercial rocket engine at Newquay airport in Cornwall.

title: lunch-club-39-s-work-makes-national-television-news
story: The Pennypit-based Preston Seton Gosford Lunchclub were featured on the news to showcase the important work that groups like this do when dealing with holiday hunger for young children.Lorna Bellany, who has been manager of the lunch club for the past year, said: ldquoIt all happened very quickly, charity Children in Scotland organised it the night before, so it was a rush to get things ready.ldquoThe kids loved it. They talked on camera about what they loved about the lunch club, which included the activities, the games and the food! They love coming here and spending time with their friends.The PSG Lunchclub runs every weekday during the holidays for two hours, providing hot food and activities including sports and music for young children. The news piece covered the need for free out of school groups for parents who cannot afford to pay for costly after school activities.Lorna continued: ldquoWe have around  children who come here every day. They come from many dferent backgrounds and have overcome many challenges.The clip was aired on the Channel  news, much to the delight of children and parents alike.Lorna added: ldquoAll the children were so excited to see themselves on TV, and I think the adults were as well!ldquoThere were a few who were upset that their interview or clip wasnrsquot shown. Everyone tuned in and it was really nice. It was great to go national, evenjust for a few minutes, and to show people the work that the lunch club does.

We went to the Co-op to get everything she needed, and they said that she could set it up outside their shop.ldquoThey even got trolleys and came up and got the stuff as we didnrsquot have a car to move it down. title: swallows-migration-inspiration-mural
story: The new artwork is a continuation of the renovation work done on the much-loved Stevenson mural in Catrsquos Close just off the townrsquos High Street.This mural had been created in - by a team of volunteers led by the late June Douglas-Hamilton but had deteriorated over time.Conservation of the old mural and creation of the new was funded by the wardrsquos area partnership and overseen by the local community council and helped by art group pARTicipate.Geraldine Prince, coordinating volunteer, said: ldquoWe aimed to preserve as much original work as possible, including the excellent Bass Rock, painted by Len Groom who passed away last year aged nearly ."The large crack in his painting has now been repaired and the elegant billowing clouds painted by his daughter Nicky Fox will also be restored by her. Andrina Wright and Tina Guy, original members of Junersquos team, are refining other areas.The new additional mural by the pARTicipate group, based on the theme of migrations, was inspired by the annual arrival of the swallows and includes a quotation from Robert Louis Stevenson, as well as his poem, lsquoSwallowsrsquo.When commenting on the tremendous creative input of pARTicipate, Dr Prince added: ldquoThe local police team, nearby residents and neighbouring traders have also helped in many ways enabling this cross-community effort to bring new le to the vennel. The cheerful enthusiasm, patient negotiation of dust sheets and ladders, and affection for the murals shown by countless hundreds of residents and visitors has been so encouraging and their support is so much appreciated by the volunteers.

title: green-fingered-judges-set-cast-eye-blooming-haddington
story: Members of Blooming Haddington have been working hard throughout the year to ensure the town is awash with colour.Two judges from Britain in Bloom visit the town on Fridayto cast their expert eye.Laura Samuel, chairwoman of the green-fingered group, was nervously looking ahead to the visit.She said: ldquoI think because we are in the British version [of the competition] there is a certain amount of nervousness. We donrsquot want to sound aswe donrsquot know what we are doing!ldquoIt is our second time in it so we know what is involved but it is new judges and they are looking for dferent things. Hopefully, it will be all right on the night.Blooming Haddington, made up entirely of hard-working volunteers, has enjoyed great success since it was formed in .The group has scooped prizes on an annual basis at the Keep Scotland Beautul awards, which were hosted in Haddington  months ago.Last year, Blooming Haddington won a gold medal and the Best Medium Town Category, which gained them qualication to the British awards.The grouprsquos chairwoman said the stakes were even higher this time around. She said: ldquoThis year, we are in with dferent parts of the country.ldquoDown south, they get a lot more heat and their plants grow a lot dferently to what they do up here.ldquoIt is slightly dferent but it is not just about horticulture but environment and community participation.Kim Parish, from Devon, will be joined by Mel Henley, in touring the town. Already,  hanging baskets have been put on display in the town centre, with patio boxes and three-tier planters also helping to add a splash of colour.Members will greet their visitors at the John Gray Centre at am.The judges and the touring party will then leave the Lodge Street venue before a tour of the town.With the countdown officially on for the judgesrsquo visit, a rigorous volunteering programme is being planned in a bid to ensure Haddingtonrsquos greenery is rewarded with gold at the national awards ceremony, which takes place in Royal Horticultural Society Halls, in Londonrsquos Vincent Square, on October .

title: man-shouted-swore-pharmacy-staff
story: Benn, of Preston Avenue, shouted and swore at employees of the Bankton Pharmacy at the townrsquos Hawthorn Road.He also behaved aggressively towards the staff members while also going on to telephone the chemist and threaten staff. He was fined pound.Benn pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing at staff and then telephoning the shop and threatening staff at the Bankton Pharmacy, between July  and August  last year.

title: watch-r-b-legend-alexander-oneal-perform-north-berwick
story: In a packed Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent at North Berwick harbour, a relaxed ONeal, , showed he had lost none of his style and showmanship - and none of his vocal talents - as he and his band had almost everyone up dancing.And in his finale, he invited anyone who wanted to to join him on the stage - and there were no shortage of takers who gave the US music legend plenty of hugs and vocal backing!Fringe by the Sea continues today and throughout the week.Todaysees David Attenborough cameraman and wildle enthusiast Doug Allan give his talk lsquoNatural Born Thrillersrsquo at the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent at pm where he discusses his adventurous career.Sir Geoff Palmer, famed human rights activist and Heriot-Watt University lecturer in Edinburgh, is presenting a talk on Historical Connections at North Berwick Library today at noonwhere he will look at the West Indies, Scotland and the slave trade.Today will also see a talk on the rewilding of Scotland with Peter Cairns a lively comic evening with Scotlandrsquos Janey Godley , andQuattro MacJazz .Tomorrowoffers the chance to relax with local Bernadette Petrie as she runs a guided meditation a chance to get inspired by feminist, activist and author Sara Sheridan : and the opportunity toput your dancing shoes on as award-winning folk band Old Blind Dogs take to the stage .Wednesday is another day for relaxation as the Barefoot Sanctuary runs mind, body and soul drop in sessions throughout the morning, and chi Kung classes with Mark Travers.Famed crime author Val McDermid joins Sir Menzies Campbell for a lunchtime conversation at midday in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent, and festival favourites Bombskare lightup the stage in the evening with their energetic music .All of this and more is on offer across North Berwick over the next six days.More information about Fringe By The Sea acts and events can be found at www.fringebythesea.

title: letter-week-dont-let-racecourse-efforts-go-waste
story: That East Lothian Council was a major force for good and catalyst for the marvellous improvements made to the course over recent years is not up for debate, and it therefore genuinely saddens me we now find ourselves in the position we are today.However, whatever the rights and wrongs on both sides of the current management debate, it is to the future that efforts and a strategic vision for the course must now be concentrated.I had the pleasure of working with many hard-working and dedicated staff from both the council and the racecourse whose sole objectives were to keep improving the racecourse experience whilst making it the lsquofive-starrsquo attraction it is today.Any future management team should not forget this.To run and manage Musselburgh Racecourse is a privilege and with that privilege comes major responsibilities. Whoever is lucky enough to take on its running must first and foremost make Musselburgh Racecourse their priority.Too much time, effort and sheer hard work has been spent in recent years by the people of Musselburgh and East Lothian to see any future benefits generated by the track invested in other ventures other than Musselburgh Racecourse.To the new management team, when appointed, I wish them good luck but Irsquod also point out that their actions and commitments to the course will no doubt be closely followed by staff, owners and trainers, bookmakers, racegoers and annual members.We have a marvellous product at Musselburgh. Letrsquos keep it that way by ensuring and committing to, the ongoing investment in the track, facilities and prizemoney. We have far too much to lose.Pat OrsquoBrien OBEChair Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee -

title: pictures-gullane-games-parade
story: The theme of the parade was Our Natural Environment, with children dressed up as everything from jellyfish to crabs and mermaids.The traditional Gullane Games races took place afterwards, with lots of activities to enjoy too such as beat the goalie, an assault course and tug-o-war.

title: floral-tribute-golfer-catriona-matthew-north-berwick-bloom
story: The carpet bed changes every year and commemorates an organisation or event that is important in the local community.The group wanted to highlight Catrionarsquos achievement in being selected as the Team Europe captain at this yearrsquos Solheim Cup at Gleneagles in September.Many months of hard work and planning, including deciding the design and layout and purchasing the plants, took place before East Lothian Council gardeners started planting.Julie Slocombe, of North Berwick in Bloom, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos display is not just about an event but an achievement, Catrionarsquos achievement, so itrsquos something a bit more special and we really wanted to commemorate that.ldquoNot only that itrsquos a big thing for womenrsquos sport and womenrsquos golf as well.Catriona, of North Berwick, is very pleased with the finished result.ldquoShe was delighted her hometown was doing this for her, said Julie, ldquoShe is a delightful lady and so professional. She said the carpet bed is looking wonderful.

title: increasing-number-youngsters-low-incomes-getting-fit-scheme
story: Last October, East Lothian Councilrsquos successful Active Schools programme introduced free access for youngsters who qualy for free school meals.Since offering free participation, the number of youngsters from lower income families taking part in the sporty activities has seen a huge increase, particular across primary schools.The number of primary school youngsters involved has doubled in some areas, with almosthalf of pupils in one primary schoolsrsquo cluster area signing up.The free activities programme was introduced after it was recommended as part of the East Lothian Poverty Commission Report in .A report on the impact of the initiativefound that more than  per cent of primary school pupils registered for free school meals joined in the activities compared to just . per cent when they had to pay.In the Musselburgh schoolsrsquo cluster, where only . per cent of children had previously taken part, it had almost trebled to . per cent.And in the Dunbar primary cluster it went from  per cent to . per cent.The report said the initiativersquos biggest impact was on primary-aged children becausethese schools had to rely on paid coaches to provide the activities.In the secondary schools where the initiative was also rolled out, the number of young people on free school meals who took part went up across the county by just under two per cent.Signicant increases were seen, however, at Dunbar Grammar School, where those signingup went from . per cent to . per cent, and at Musselburgh Grammar School, where it went from . per cent to . per cent.The report said that the free activities policy had been extended to looked-after children too.It added: ldquoThe free access policy is one of a number of methods used to engage with low income families.ldquoAn increasing number of referrals are being received from colleagues to help remove the stigma and barriers associated with poverty.ldquoActive Schools will continue to provide the appropriate interventions and opportunities for children in receiptof free school meals to ensure the service plays its part in contributing to the East Lothian Poverty Commission report and in tackling inequalities.Active Schools is a joint initiative between East Lothian Council and Sport Scotland.Its main aim is to offer school-aged children the motivation and opportunities to adopt active, healthy lestyles throughout their school years.Parents who are able to pay for term-time blocks of after-school activities ranging from football and rugby to street dance and rock climbing do so.

title: woman-admonished-following-incident-child-aged-9
story: Ewa Wilson shouted and swore before taking a nine-year-old child to a room within an address in Portobello, Edinburgh, and preventing others from gaining entry.Wilson, of Musselburgh High Street, denied the offence and stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year where she was found guilty.Wilson was also alleged to have assaulted Jonathan Wilson and to struggling with him but that charge was found not proven.The -year-old had her sentence deferred for a year for her to prove she could stay out of trouble.And in court last Thursday, Sherf Michael OrsquoGrady QC was told Wilson had been of good behaviour and he handed out an admonishment.

title: woman-cycles-1-500-miles-mums-old-bike-memory
story: Juliette Camburn, who grew up near Athelstaneford, has raised more than pound, for the cancer support charity Maggiersquos after herself beating cancer in  and her mum Sue passing away of breast cancer in January of this year.Juliette, along with her partner Francis Hayes, completed the epic charity ride where they visited every UK Maggiersquos Cancer Caring Centre, travelling the same distance as Landrsquos End to John OrsquoGroats twice over and twice the height of Mount Everest.The keen cyclists, who now live in Stirling, set out on June , and travelled around northern Scotland, south Wales, London, northern England and finished on June  at their starting point at Maggiersquos Cancer Care Centre in Edinburgh.Juliette, , said of the challenge: ldquoI used my mumrsquos bike, a -year-old Dawes Galaxy, and it definitely felt like she was with me all the way round. We got to see parts of the country that we hadnrsquot seen before and visiting all the centres reminded us that the money we are raising is going to such a good cause.On the final stretch, Juliette was joined by her sister Jess, and father Martyn, who now live in Drem, who jumped on their bikes to ride side by side as they finished the journey in Edinburgh.Juliette continued: ldquoThe last three days from Gateshead to Edinburgh Maggiersquos was a high ndash we had glorious sunshine, beautul coastal route and being joined on the last day by my family and one of my best friends who also lost her mum to cancer this year. We had a picnic on Portobello beach on the way!ldquoAfter completing our epic journey, Maggiersquos Edinburgh welcomed us back and the staff and volunteers had laid on a buffet with fizz.Despite these highs, the long journey came with its own problems as Juliette explained: ldquoJune wasnrsquot the best month weather-wise: there were lots of long days when we were wet from start to finish, we were never cold though.ldquoWe got lost a few times, especially in the cities, and I had a niggle in my left knee on day two which got really painful over the next few days and was hard mentally, knowing we still had so far to go. Luckily my body just adapted to being on the bike and the pain went away.ldquoI was happy to get to do this challenge with my partner Francis who kept me going with his humour, patience and support.Donate via Juliettersquos Just Giving page:www.justgiving fundraising julesfrancismaggies

title: milestone-reached-ahead-letham-mains-primary-school-opening-next-year
story: The -tonne steel frame for Letham Mains Primary School, which will be home to  pupils, has now been completed by Morrison Construction.Work began on the pound. million school, which will be at the heart of more than  homes on Haddingtonrsquos western edge, in April.The superstructure, including steel work, pre-cast concrete installation and a first-floor reinforced concrete slab, was completed during a -week schedule. Once complete, the school will feature  classrooms suitable for pre-school and primary teaching, a dining hall, social space and a two-court PE hall with retractable seating for performance and community use.Outdoors will be designed for outdoor learning, physical education and play.The school is being funded entirely by contributions from housing developers.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoItrsquos really exciting to see the progress thatrsquos being made on our newest primary school.ldquoHaving the steel frame in place gives a better idea of the size and scale of the building and the facilities that the school will offer for children and their families.ldquoIrsquom also pleased to see the amount of engagement that Morrison Construction is undertaking within the local community to ensure the benefits of the project are already being felt.

title: former-belhaven-parish-church-minister-reveals-love-east-lothian-remains
story: The Rev Laurence Twaddle was minister at Belhaven linked with Spott for almost  years before swapping the East Lothian coast for the Alps in January .He took up the role of minister for the Church of Scotland in Geneva, Switzerland, where he was joined by we Lindy, who was previously headteacher at Macmerry Primary School.Mr Twaddle, who was succeeded by the Rev Neil Watson in East Lothian, told the Courier he was enjoying le in Switzerlandrsquos second biggest city.He said: ldquoLe in Geneva is wonderful ndash a great climate, stunning mountain scenery. It is always full of interest ndash lovely cafes, restaurants and little markets ndash and very handy for trips to fabulous locations but it will never be West Barns!ldquoOne of the first things to strike you when you get here is how expensive everything is clean, organised, calm but expensive!ldquoLiving in the city might not seem very appealing after the delights of John Muir Country Park and Belhaven Bay but there is amazingly good public transport.And being from where we are, within very easy reach of France, rivers, hills and forests, you can almost forget you are living in an apartment, and not a lovely old Scottish manse.Switzerland is exactly as you would imagine it: chocolate box chalets, the Alps are breath-taking, gorgeous lakes aplenty and a train system that makes travel relaxed and pleasant.Mr Twaddle, who was also hospital chaplain at Belhaven Hospital and the club chaplain for Dunbar United FC, stressed there was plenty to miss about East Lothian ndash including Dunbar United and the Courier ndash although Geneva ldquokind of felt like home.ldquoI certainly do miss East Lothian as a place, he added.ldquoThe sea and the harbour at Dunbar, walks with the dogs in Tyninghame woods, coffee at Graze [in Dunbar], a busy High Street where you bump into people and share a greeting.ldquoThis rarely happens in a big city context and it is a precious thing that you donrsquot appreciate till you donrsquot have it!ldquoAnd the people ndash who are still engraved on my heart and always will be.ldquoWe came back for my daughterrsquos wedding last November and I still have the same wonderful dentist, so there are two visits a year.It is cheaper to fly over and have my twice yearly check up than pay for it in Geneva!ldquoWersquove been really fortunate to have lots of visitors come over since we came here and I do keep in touch with people.ldquoThe friendships and love of those  years or so donrsquot just stop overnight and never will.

title: diamond-couple-toast-wedding-anniversary
story: Ruth and Jimmy Good from North Seton Park celebrated  years of marriage with a stunning white wedding cake at a reception at Bellany Day Centre, followed a few days later by an evening at the Longniddry Inn.Ruth, , said: ldquoMy husband attends the Bellany Centre."The manager, Ann invited us down to celebrate our anniversary."We walked in and everyone cheered, we all danced and then went through to cut the cake."It was all done up like a wedding reception.ldquoJimmy and I met in Edinburgh, wersquore both from there originally, only moving out here about  years ago. We met at the Palais in Fountainbridge.The Palais de Danse was one of the most popular nights out in the city in its heyday, playing host to the BBC series Come Dancing, before closing its doors in .Ruth continued: ldquoWe didnrsquot go on a honeymoon or anything, in those days you could not really afford it. You just went back to work and got on with things.Ruth and Jimmy, , even received a card from the Queen congratulating them for reaching this milestone.She said: ldquoThe letter from the Queen was so lovely."It says that she is pleased to know that we are celebrating our diamond wedding anniversary and she sends us congratulations."She has signed it Elizabeth. Even the picture on the front of the card, she looks so beautul. It really was wonderful.So, what is the secret to a -year marriage  Ruth laughed: ldquoNo idea! I suppose itrsquos really important to get on well with each other."Yoursquore going to have your ups and downs everyone does and thatrsquos OK.

title: council-happy-exam-results-picture
story: And the good news is that there has been an increase in the number of young people from East Lothian achieving A-C grades in National  qualications.However, the local authority has not yet released a detailed picture of how pupils performed at Higher and Advanced Higher level.According to this years Scottish Qualications Authorityresults, exam pass rates across Scotland have fallen at every level except National .In an early snapshot of how the students performed, East Lothian Council has released its lsquokey highlightsrsquo of the results, which focuses mainly on National  qualications.They say:Fiona Robertson, head of education at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoThese results reflect positively on the work in our schools to offer a broad range of qualications and opportunities."I welcome the increase in National  qualications presented at S level and the pass rate rise, which gives our young people a good grounding for their senior phase."A  per cent pass rate at English, its highest level in five years, is very encouraging and Irsquom pleased to see we are continuing steady results in maths which has been an area of focus for this authority and across the South East Improvement Collaborative ."Congratulations to all our young people on their results, and to our schools for the work that they have undertaken to support learning.A total of , resulted awards were certicated for , candidates across the county this year.

title: traffic-diverted-macmerry-tranent-westbound-section-a1-closed
story: Resurfacing works are taking place on the westbound carriage of the A between Gladsmuir and Tranent.Motorists will be erted off the A at Gladsmuir before re-joining the road at the Bankton junction.The roadworks are due to take place each night from pm to .am. They resulted in particularly heavy traffic through Macmerry and Tranent on Monday evening. The eastbound carriageway is open as usual.

title: filming-taking-place-port-seton-high-street
story: A short film called Fishing by LS Productions means that a rolling road closure has been created.This is when the road is mainly open, but traffic will be lsquopausedrsquo to clear the road at times.It is a system commonly used in cycling and road events.There will also be parking restrictions in place.When asked, LS Productions marketing team informed the Courier that due to signing non-disclosure agreements, they were unable to say anything more about the film.

title: football-temporarily-closes-refurbished-aubigny-swimming-pool
story: The Aubigny Sports Centrersquos swimming pool had been closed from April until last month as part of a pound, makeover.However, it was temporarily closed again on Monday thanks to an errantly kicked football.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council told the Courier the pool was closed to the general public from about am to noon.She added: ldquoA football had been kicked onto the roof of the Aubigny outwith the knowledge of the staff team which caused an obstruction in an external downpipe, resulting in a small leak in the changing room area.ldquoThe issue was quickly fixed and remedial action is being taken to prevent such occurrences in the future.ldquoThe pool reopened by lunchtime on the same day.During the poolrsquos planned closure earlier this summer, essential maintenance and internal deacutecor works were carried out.The two pools were drained, with a new light, modern, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.Improvements were made in the changing rooms as well, with the pool and surrounding area given a deep clean.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centre and opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in .

title: nungate-gala-gets-tartan
story: Last year, a call was made for Nungate residents to come up with their own design for a Nungate Tartan.More than a dozen entries were submitted, with the design of local resident Kate Cowan coming out on top .The concept was then registered and produced by Strathmore Weavers.ldquoThe Nungate has a long history and has always had a strong identity of its own, said Liz McDougall, chairwoman of the Nungate Gala Committee.ldquoWhen the suggestion came from dressmaker Paula Fairbairn for us to consider getting our own kilts for the gala day court, it sparked the idea of creating our very own Nungate tartan.ldquoIt seemed to me that it would be appropriatethe design came from the community itself, so thatrsquos how we have taken things forward, and through this journey, we have had support from Tesco.ldquoAt this yearrsquos gala, we will have more boys than ever in the queenrsquos court ndash all kitted out in kilts to showcase the tartan."We are very proud of our tartan and are delighted that it will be on show at this yearrsquos gala day.Gala celebrations get under way at noon this Saturday and run through to pm.The crowning of this yearrsquos Gala Queen, Olivia McCulloch, takes place at .pm followed by a procession through Haddington.Among the attractions at the gala are a bonnie baby and fancy dress competition, as well as plenty for youngsters including bouncy castles and other rides.There will also be a demonstration from WL Wrestling to mark the rd Nungate Gala.The gala committee chairwoman added: ldquoAnyone with a connection with the Nungate or who simply likes the tartan will have the opportunity to purchase it and have it made into kilts and other items, all of which will bring some additional funds into the community.ldquoMore importantly, the tartan is a great way for the Nungate to demonstrate that it is a vibrant community which takes pride in its own identity and has its own people at its heart ndash something which is also a foundation for our gala.ldquoWe hope everyone who comes along on Saturday likes the tartan and has a great day.

title: man-fractured-pelvis-waits-90-minutes-ambulance
story: Richard Gardner was making his way home from North Berwick on his electric moped when he was struck by the vehicle.The accident left the -year-old lying on the road with a fractured pelvis, as well as a head wound and ious wounds to his knees and legs.He said: ldquoI was ing home after I was playing petanque in North Berwick and I was driving along the main road coming into Dirleton from North Berwick.ldquoAs I got to the Station Road junction, a car pulled out and knocked me off my electric moped.ldquoThe ambulance was called immediately and when the police arrived an hour later, they checked on the ambulance and there did not seem to be one allocated.ldquoIt was over an hour and a half before it got to me.ldquoIt was two and a half hours before I got to the hospital.Now, Richard, who lives off Dirletonrsquos Manse Road, has questioned why it took the ambulance so long to reach him in Dirleton andthis is a regular occurrence.He is chairman of the Dirleton Village Association and said: ldquoWe are concerned, and have been before, that emergency services are very slow to reach our village.ldquoWe are raising the matter with the Dirleton Village Association, with a view to enquiring with the Scottish Ambulance Service as to what the situation is regarding services, priorities and vulnerabilities.Mr Gardner, who previously worked as a solicitor with Drummond Miller in Musselburgh before he retired, has stayed in the village for four years.He highlighted that Dirleton, which is home to more than  people, has a high percentage of elderly residents.He added: ldquoIrsquom going to be asking for a personal explanation but I am interested in the bigger picture.Tom Drysdale also lives in the village and is the chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, which also covers Dirleton.He said the issue had been ldquonoted as a matter of concern in the village.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoIf it took an hour and a bit to come to Dirleton it would have taken the same time to come to North Berwick or Gullane.ldquoAlthough it was a fracture, it could have been a heart attack.ldquoIt was unfortunate.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Ambulance Service apologised to Mr Gardner.She said: ldquoUnfortunately this patient waited longer than we would have liked and we would like to apologise ndash our calls are prioritised to ensure that the sickest and most seriously injured patients are given the highest priority and we were experiencing a high level of demand at the time.ldquoWe regret that the patient waited longer than we would have liked and we will be contacting the patient directly to apologise and to investigate further.

title: giant-leeks-catch-eye-national-judges
story: Alan Manning was a winner at the National Vegetable Societyrsquos National Championships, which took place at Brockenhurst, in the New Forest, at the end of last month.The -year-old won the pot leek class ndash  years after he won the long leeks section.He said: ldquoIn the past, I have shown all sorts of vegetables and have won national championships with parsnips.ldquoWith retiring this year, I really concentrated on the leeks and I have got a few onions but nothing  of exhibition equality.Mr Manning, who lives on the Clint Estate, near Stenton, has been growing leeks for a number of years and would regularly donate any left over to the annual Save the Children country market in Haddington.He said: ldquoIrsquom from the north-east of England and leeks are predominantly what was grown in the villages."Where I grew up, everybody was growing pot leeks and one of the staples diets was leek pudding and broth.Mr Manning, who is moving from the area to head back to his native north-east, was on the front page of the Courier when he previously won in .It read: ldquoBest of the best. . . that is the leeks grown by horticultural maestro Alan Manning.ldquoAlan from Stenton won the prestigious National Vegetable Societyrsquos first prize for vegetables at the recent Dundee Flower Show.ldquoThe award is the number one accolade for members of the green-fingered fraternity ndash the Crufts of the veggie world.

title: surge-39-struggling-39-families-sees-demand-kids-39-lunch-club-soar
story: More than  children took part in this summerrsquos club compared to just  when it began in .And Universal Credit has been blamed for the dramatic increase in families who need help providing their children with a healthy meal, during the holidays.Sandra King, from Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership, who help fund the club, which runs in Prestonpans and Tranent, said there was no doubt the impact of East Lothian being used to pilot the roll-out of Universal Credit was being witnessed.She said: ldquoIt is like being back in the Seventies: the number of families who are struggling and need support is high and the Universal Credit pilot in East Lothian has definitely had an impact.The outward appearance of East Lothian as an affluent county was misleading, she added, with families in all of its town and communities struggling.She said: ldquoEven in places like North Berwick we are seeing families affected. It is an issue which touches every community.The club, which is run by Fundamental Foods, began in Prestonpans after local headteacher Sheila Laing highlighted the struggle some families faced and has extended to a second base in Tranent.In Prestonpans, they moved the club into Preston Tower Primary School this year from the Pennypit Pagoda because they needed more space.In Tranent, it operates at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School.Both the Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership and Farsquoside Area Partnership help fund the holiday club with money given to them by East Lothian Council as part of their food poverty strategy.The local authority set up a short-le working group to look at how to tackle food poverty following the establishment of East Lothian Poverty Commission in .The group looked specically at ways to help children and young people who need support for ldquoholiday and every day hunger.One of their key actions is to support and develop breakfast, after school and summer lunch clubs in schools.As well as providing daily activities and healthy meals for youngsters, the club in Prestonpans and Tranent has a pantry stocked with food and available for everyone to help themselves to items they need as they enter and leave the club.Local branches of Tesco, Aldi and the Co-op regularly supply the club with leftover food and  staff and volunteers run the club, at both its centres, including an additional support needs specialist.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods which is part of the Prestonpans-based Pennypit Trust, said children come from all over the Preston Seton Gosford and neighbouring Farsquoside wards to the club. Most are referred.She said local knowledge allows them to identy families who need extra help through the community.Ruth said: ldquoIt is really important children can access healthy food and can be dficult for parents during school holidays.ldquoWe have a number of families with a lot of children and provide a service for children aged three to . Some of the older children come back and volunteer as well.As well as food, the club provides free toiletries and took the youngsters on trips over the holidays to places such as East Links Family Park, Dunbar.And free haircuts were provided by Cockenzie-based Unique salon.This week the club has been replaced with a unorm swap shop as school s next week.

title: archerfield-cup-grabs-musselburgh-racecourse
story: Locals and visitors to East Lothian can enjoy seven action-packed races featuring prize money of more than pound, and a host of free family entertainment.Attractions for those with young children includes free funfair rides and face painting. Children aged under  are admitted for free when accompanied by an adult.Gates open at noon and the first race gets underway at .pm.The feature race on the card is the pound, Glenrath Farms Archerfield Cupover m f and the support race is the pound, EBF Conditional Stakes five furlong sprint .Musselburgh Racecourse marketing manager Susan Findlay, said: ldquoFor families in the middle of that long summer holiday period our family day is a great alternative to the beach or other tried and tested family treats.ldquoWhile the action takes place on the track there is plenty of free entertainment to interest our younger visitors.Purchasing an Early Bird ticket by midnight tonight, Thursday, will save racegoers pound on the usual pound entry free.For those travelling from further afield, free courtesy buses from and ing to Wallyford and Newcraighall rail stations are provided.To book tickets, visitwww.musselburgh-racecourse

title: thousands-spent-musselburgh-racecourse-buildings
story: The independent report on the condition of buildings at the historic course found the majority of it was in a satisfactory condition.However, it was critical of areas used by staff, which were in some parts described as being in a ldquopoor state.It said the racecourse workshop, which houses both staff from the course and other East Lothian Council amenity services, required an overhaul, calling for flooring which it described as ldquovery dirty to be given a deep clean ndash and the toilet facilities too.It said: ldquoThe electric shower, ceramic WCs and wash hand basins with chrome taps are in a poor condition and are either damagedor require a deep clean.East Lothian Council is currently seeking a third-party operator for the course, which is currently overseen by the Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee .The survey was carried out ahead of the tendering process to ensure the facilities were up to standard.The report acknowledged the age of some of the older buildings on the site but highlighted missing ceiling tiles and grouting work which needed to be fixed.It also urged operators to have a fire risk assessment carried out for the main grandstand to ensure the fire breaks in its roof space are sufficient.The report was one of a number which were presented to MRAC in private at the end of last year.They have now been released to the public under the Freedom of Information Act.It is understood that local tradespeople are being used to carry out the work detailedin the survey, which is expected to cost substantially less than the independent estimate of pound,.Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: ldquoWork is in progress to maintain standards around ious parts of the racecourse and the expenditure is reasonable for a sporting and leisure facility which welcomes , visitors a year.

title: childrens-clothing-sparks-late-night-search
story: Police and North Berwick RNLI were called out after a member of the pulic raised the alarm.A search of the water was launched with North Berwick and Dunbar Coastguard teams and a rescue helicopter joining in after the discover at the old pier around .pm.The items found were a small black t-shirt with Japanese writing, pictures and symbols on it, a plain grey short sleeved t-shirt, a hoodie for a child aged - and a blue multicoloured towel with large orange stripe down the centre and two large fish.Police said no missing person reports were lodged however, searches took place in the area as a precaution.White flares were also used to assist the crews in their search of the area.The search was called off after an hour and the incident described by police as a " alarm with good intent".A spokesperson for North Berwick RNLI said: ldquoIt is suspected that the clothing may have been left by a swimmer earlier in the day.Teenagers have been seenin recent weeks harbour jumping at North Berwick during good weather. One theory is that the clothing items and towel were mistakenly left by one of these youngsters.

title: five-things-east-lothian-weekend
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do between this eveningand Sunday.Whether it is gala day celebrations or caber-tossing and tug-of-war, there is something for everyone.. Nungate GalaA SPECIAL tartan is to be unveiled this weekend to mark the Nungate Gala celebrations.Last year, a call was made for Nungate residents to come up with their own design for a Nungate Tartan.More than a dozen entries were submitted, with the design of local resident Kate Cowan coming out on top.The concept was then registered and produced by Strathmore Weavers.Gala celebrations get under way at noon tomorrowand run through to pm.The crowning of this yearrsquos Gala Queen, Olivia McCulloch, takes place at .pm followed by a procession through Haddington.Among the attractions at the gala are a bonnie baby and fancy dress competition, as well as plenty for youngsters including bouncy castles and other rides.There will also be a demonstration from WL Wrestling to mark the rd Nungate Gala.. North Berwick Highland GamesA HUGE crowd is expected at tomorrowsNorth Berwick International Highland Games.The Recreation Park gathering is the Gamesrsquo th anniversary.There is lots on offer from traditional heavy events to music, sport, childrenrsquos rides and trade stalls.Performances from  pipe bands from more than  countries give the day a truly international feel.Highland dancers of ious ages will be performing a number of traditional Scottish dances to crowds in the south west corner of the park.The heavy events include tossing the caber, throwing the hammer and tug of war.The main arena will play host to a -yard sprint for the first time, with ious handicap races planned.Around the park, there will be ious craft and trade stalls, childrenrsquos rides and a demonstration from the Lammermuir Stick Dressing Society.The Games begin at am at Recreation Park.. Fringe by the SeaWHETHER you like comedy, literature or live music, there is plenty on on offer in North Berwick.The curtain comes down on Fringe by the Sea on Sunday but there is still much to see before then.Tomorrow , Channel  journalist Cathy Newman is in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent at am.We know of Emmeline Pankhurst, Vera Brittain, Marie Stopes and Beatrice Webb.But who remembers engineer and motorbike racer Beatrice Shilling, who fixed an often-fatal flaw in the Spitfire, allowing the RAFrsquos planes to soar to victory Cathy Newmans book Bloody Brilliant Women looks at some of the pioneering women in history.Then, at pm, in the same venue, there is a chance to hear from Ian Rankin.The much-celebrated Scottish author has seen his books starring John Rebus translated into  dferent languages and sold in their millions.Eddi Reader rounds off the night on Saturday from pm.Then, on Sunday, Lord David Steel is in conversation with Gordon Brown from noon in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent.A Pet Shop Boys Tribute then performs at pm in the same venue.For more, go to www.fringebythesea. Ladies Scottish OpenTOP quality golfing is on display at The Renaissance Club tomorrowand Sunday.The Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is due to come to a close on Sunday.Thailands Ariya Jutanugarn won the competition  months ago at nearby Gullane Golf Club but can she repeat the feat at another county course Unfortunately, it looks like Catriona Matthews chances of winning are over.The North Berwick-based golfer is on + after completing her two rounds and is unlikely to make the cut.Entry to the event is free of charge.. FootballTHREE of the countys senior football teams are at home on Saturday.Haddington Athletic welcome Leith Athletic along the A to Millfield.The visitors sit second in the table with two wins and a draw from the opening three games.Meanwhile, Joe Hamills Hi Hi know they cannot afford many slip ups in a league where only one team is guaranteed promotion.They have picked up four points from their opening three games and will be hoping that home advantage is key.Alex Jack Cup action takes centre stage in Dunbar and Musselburgh.Dunbar United have enjoyed a promising start to their Premier Division season and will be looking to back that up against Dunipace.The Denny-based side are in the same league as Haddington Athletic and have six points from their opening three games.Finally, Musselburgh welcome Peebles Rovers - another Conference A team - to Olive Bank.The visitorsare yet to taste victory this season, with Musselburgh having picked up a - win over Sauchie Juniors last time out.All three games kick-off at .pm.

title: boys-14-secure-fringe-sea-gig
story: Top names for the music world, comedians and literary circles have all graced the festivals Spiegeltents over the past week.Now added to that roll of honour are indie-rockers Shoegazers - made up of four North Berwick High School -year-olds who practice in the school music department at lunch-times.Jason Lovell , Sam Cowan , Luke Smithand Fraser McCarterhave so far only performed at private parties.So to have their first gig at Fringe by the Sea is quite an achievement - and a challenge!A mixture of their favourite tracks will be played along with some original songs.World-famous crime writer Ian Rankin follows the performance on Saturday so the band will play a punk track to honour his taste in music.The boys gig, at noon in the the Lighthouse Spiegeltent,is free but donations can be made toNorth Berwicks Beach Wheelchairs charity.

title: gerry-cinnamon-announces-second-glasgow-hydro-gig-popular-demand

title: iain-macwhirter-john-mcdonnells-edinburgh-declaration-caught-scottish-political-world-completely-surprise
story: If anyone tells you that theyd expected this, theyre lying. McDonnells Edinburgh Declaration caught the Scottish political world completely by surprise. The SNP couldnt believe their ears. I initially thought his remarks, especially the reference to ldquothe English Parliament, were just a badly-briefed UK politician talking off the cuff. But no. It is now apparently UK Labour policy to accept the SNPrsquos call for ldquoindyref. Gobs were well and truly smacked.Most smacked of all were the Scottish Labour Partys. Their leader, Richard Leonard, was left speechless. The Shadow Chancellor had directly contradicted Labours  manesto promise to oppose a repeat referendum. Only in March, Leonard made clear in an interview with the Daily Record, that a future Labour government would, like Theresa May, refuse any request for a ldquoSection  Order to trigger a legally-binding referendum on independence. No s no buts.:Scottish Labour registers lowest level of income in nearly two decadesNot any more, it seems. The Branch Office, as the SNP like to call Scottish Labour, has been told to back the policy of their deadly enemy. Christmas has come early for Nicola Sturgeon, without the turkeys.Many Scottish Labour MSPs were incandescent, as was the former Labour shadow Scottish secretary Ian Murray MP, who called McDonnell ldquoludicrous and demanded that he ldquoapologise to Richard Leonard , and reaffirm Labours policy of opposition to a referendum . Off-the-record comments from Scottish Labour figures were unprintable. Unionist Labour MSPs put together a statement ldquodeploring" the change in policy. This backfired when it emerged they hadnt cleared it with Richard Leonards office.The Labour MP, Paul Sweeney, then added to the confusion by calling for a multi-option referendum including federalism, or devo max as it used to be called. This was once proposed by Alex Salmond in , and rejected by Labour and the Conservatives in favour of a binary Yes No question. Saying Labour were all over the place would be an insult to geography.So, what on earth is going on  Why was one of the key figures in the UK Labour party provoking a split on one of the most contentious issues in British politics  And right in the middle of the Brexit row. Labour is now ided every which way on the constitution: over Scottish independence and over leaving Europe. McDonnell has left the Scottish party an impossible task: trying to win Scottish votes without a policy on Scotland in a general election thats possibly weeks away.:Scottish Labour breaks silence over anti-semitism investigation by blasting "biased" BBCWhat seems to have happened is this. Labour, at a UK level, has started to think about forming much wider political alliances in future in order to defeat the rising tide of the right. This has been discussed by a number of Labour people, including the former BBC economics editor Paul Mason in his book Clear Bright Future.Mason has argues that Labour should abandon its traditional base in the white working class and the trades union movement, and look to creating a new progressive alliance, or ldquopopular front, with LGBT and BAME groups, and with other progressive political parties. Mason regards the SNP, unlike most other nationalist parties, as progressive and social democratic. On the eve of McDonnells Edinburgh interview Mason called infor ldquoa penalty-free independence referendum whenever Holyrood chooses.Im not saying that Paul Mason is writing Labour policy. Far from it. Many in the party regard him with suspicion, not least for appearing to abandon the working class. But it looks asthe Labour leadership has finally been persuaded that the SNP is not just a band of ldquotartan Tories, and that Jeremy Corbyn could do business with Nicola Sturgeon.Scottish Labour is anyway likely to be crushed again in the forthcoming General Wlection, while the SNP is in line for around  Westminster seats according to the polls. Its support would almost certainly be requiredLabour is to try to form a government, and McDonnells intervention could be an attempt to prepare the ground. Theres been no love lost between Corbyn and the mostly Blairite rump of the Scottish Labour Party, so he probably regards them as expendable.Not that Labour is admitting any of this. Indeed, the line from McDonnell in Edinburgh, echoed by the Shadow Business Secretary, Rebecca Long-Bailey on Newsnight, is that Labour will not form any ldquocoalitions or pacts with anyone. Labour is still smarting from those Tory election posters in  which showed the then leader, Ed Miliband, in Alex Salmonds breast pocket. It is imperative for Labour, in England at least, to deny any hint of an alliance with the SNP.But Scotland is a dferent. A ing Labour government in Westminster would require the tacit assistance of the SNP, perhaps on a confidence and supply basis. At any rate, the UK party leadership seems to have decided that offering a referendum is a risk worth taking to help some future co-operation to happen. This is huge development and raises questions about whether Labour can still be called a Unionist party.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationLast week felt asa dam has broken. After three years in which Scottish politics has been in suspended animation, suddenly everyone was talking about independence again. Even Conservative commentators like The Times Iain Martin are now calling for a referendum in five years. s Simon Jenkins believes independence itself is now unavoidable, and called on Westminster to plan for it now.Of course, a referendum may not deliver a Yes. The polls still show Scotland split down the middle on independence. But this is a vindication of Nicola Sturgeons cautious, constitutional approach to winning independence. It is a blow to her critics, who had been calling for an unauthorised referendum, or even UDI. The former SNP MP, George Kerevan, had been calling for mass civil disobedience to obstruct London transport. But this is a blow her internal critics will be happy to take for there is now a real possibility of a referendum in the next couple of years.That isLabour manages to defeat Boris Johnson ndash a big ask, perhaps, but far from impossible. There will likely be a vote of no confidence the Tory PM next month, and he will almost certainly lose. If Labour fails to form an alternative government in  days, then Johnson has to call a General Election. Hes hoping to delay polling day until after Brexit on October . But that is a risky tactic. Such constitutional jiggery pokery could easily alienate voters, many of whom are anyway unconvinced by Johnsons abilities.Just about anything could happen in the next few weeks. But what is not in doubt is that Scottish independence, or at least a referendum, is back on the agenda. And almost exactly five years since the last one.

title: revealed-uk-shoppers-want-39-perfect-39-community-high-street
story: In a land of strip malls, edge-of-town supermarkets and soulless retail parks, shoppers still dream of traditional mom and pop stores.A survey , adults has found a real community shopping street should have baker, a butcher, a barber, post office, and hardware store.And even in an era of downloads, those surveyed said they would want a record shop.So we all know want makes the perfect high street. But where can we find them Well, forty are now vying to be officially named the best in Britain - based on their shopping experience and community initiatives.In Scotland, Turrf and Alness High Street are in the running alongside Prestwick Main Street, while Wales has Narbeth, Treorchy and Swansea High Streets under consideration.English high streets shortlisted in the Champion High Street Category are Hitchin Town Centre, Freeman Street in Grimsby and Belper in Derbyshire.For Northern Irish shoppers, Newtownards High Street, Enniskillen Town Centre and Bow Street, Lisburn, are up for the prize.The eventual winner will be required to demonstrate their commitment to their local community, great customer experience, an environmental mindset and innovative approach to retail.Judges will also visit each destination on the shortlist, to get a feel for its personality and general ambience.The winning street will be awarded the coveted Great British High Street  trophy, and a pound, cash prize to put towards a local high street initiative.The announcement follows research commissioned by Visa, in partnership with the Great British High Street demonstrating the positive impact the local high street has on communities.Seven in  consumers say shopping locally makes them feel happier, compared to shopping online or at a shopping centre - the main reason being that they know where their money is going.Half of consumers also feel their high street gives them a sense of pride in their local community.Spending time with friends and familyand offering a sense of communitywere other reasons cited for why high streets make people happier.After a rigorous selection process,  high streets from the South East of England to the Scottish Highlands have been shortlisted in the Champion High Street category, which recognises the nationrsquos best high streets.Additionally,  high streets have been shortlisted in the Rising Star category, identying those which are taking the lead to adapt and ersy.Sundeep Kaur, head of UK  Ireland merchant services at Visa, said: ldquoWersquove seen some fantastic entries for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards across both the Champion High Street and Rising Star categories.ldquoIn particular, the desire to innovate stands out among this yearrsquos entries, with high streets adapting to the challenges presented by a rapidly changing retail environment to find ways to thrive at a local level.ldquoAs our research shows, high streets play a vital role at the heart of communities, so this is a great opportunity for those communities with shortlisted high streets to show their support by placing their votes on the Great British High Street website.Last yearrsquos winner was Crickhowell High Street in Wales, located in a bustling rural town nestled in the Usk Valley on the edge of the Brecon BeaconsIt was commended for its community-led initiatives and strong network of independent businesses.High Streets Minister Jake Berry MP said: ldquoCongratulations to the shortlisted nominees for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards ndash the quality of the entries this year has been fantastic.ldquoHigh streets make people happier, and people want to see their hard-earned cash supporting the local economy.ldquoThat is why we are celebrating those that go above and beyond to keep their high streets thriving for generations to come.ldquoInspiring high streets like these will play a key role in the Governmentrsquos vision to boost local growth and level up our regions.Out-of-town malls and online shopping have decimated community high streets. But this week Doug Gurr, UK boss of Amazon, the worlds biggest internet vendor, insisted physical retail ndash which is  per cent of UK shopping by value ndash was working hand-in-hand with e-commerce working to drive growth.Shortlisted high streets ndash Champion High Street categoryEngland.
