title: former-sturgeon-adviser-snp-lib-dems-unite-wipe-tories
story: Noel Dolan, who was Nicola Sturgeonrsquos most senior adviser for nine years, and his Lib Dem-supporting we Judith Fryer have urged the parties to form a one-off lsquoRemainrsquo alliance to defeat all thirteen Conservative MPs.They told this newspaper: ldquoWe should remember that it is the thirteen Scottish Tories who ndash along with the  Democratic Unionist Party MPs ndash are giving Boris Johnson his bare Commons majority. It is essential that Remain parties take these seats.An SNP spokesperson did not reject the idea: "The SNP has consistently worked with other parties to ensure that the livelihoods of citizens across the UK are not destroyed by a disastrous No-Deal Brexit. As was made clear at the the European elections, the best way to beat the Tories in Scotland is to vote SNP.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationPrime Minister Johnson has put Westminster on a general election footing after dropping hints that a poll is on its way.Any election would be dominated by Brexit and he is expected to frame it as the Tories standing up to parties that want to revisit the  referendum result.The recent by-election in Brecon and Radnorshire showed how dominant an issue Brexit has become, with the Lib Dems clinching victory after the pro-Remain Greens and Plaid Cymru opted against fielding a candidate.The cross-party pact has led to similar calls in Scotland, which overwhelmingly voted to stay in the EU.The SNP, Lib Dems, Greens and Scottish Labour all support another vote on leaving the EU, with the Tories and the Brexit Party pushing for withdrawal.Dolan first started to work for Sturgeon in  when she was depute SNP leader and was by her side in Government as her senior special adviser until his retirement in .From  to , Fryer worked for the Liberal Democrats in Westminster and was head of Press and Broadcasting. She stood for the party in two Holyrood elections.Picture: Judith FryerTheir proposal is for the SNP, Lib Dems and Greens to put aside their dferences on independence and agree a pact in the thirteen seats won by the Scottish Tories in .SNP veteran: Wings over Scotland plan for a new party could "split" pro-indy voteThey said: ldquoThroughout the Brexit process the Conservatives have ignored the wishes of the people of Scotland and shown their complete disdain for our country. They are now pushing through an extreme version of Brexit, supported by the  Scottish Tories.ldquoOver the three years since the  referendum, the Remain parties have not yet managed to work constructively or in a coherent way to stop Brexit.Dolan and Fryer continued: ldquoThis will undoubtedly be a Brexit election and the SNP, Lib Dems and Greens should put aside their other dferences and come together to defeat the Conservatives in the  seats that they currently hold in Scotland.ldquoThis would be a one-off arrangement and would only apply to the  Tory-held seats, not to the  non-Tory seats in Scotland where normal political activity would apply."They argue that the Lib Dems and Greens should make way for the SNP as the ldquoagreed Remain party by not standing in ten of the thirteen seats: Aberdeen South Angus Ayr, Carrick and Cumnock Banff and Buchan Dumfries and Galloway East Renfrewshire Moray Ochil and South Perthshire Stirling and Dumfrieesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale.Dolan and Fryer also propose that the SNP stand aside for the Lib Dems in three constituencies - Gordon, West Aberdeenshire  Kincardine, and Berwickshire, Roxburgh  Selkirk - where the Nationalists are currently in second place to the Tories.They explained: ldquoThe SNP is the dominant force in Scottish politics but there should be no place for any assumption that they can win these  seats by themselves. Nor should SNP dominance be overstated. In the last two elections, the SNP share of the vote was % in the  General Election and % in the recent European elections.ldquoLearn the lesson of Brecon and Radnorshire, come to an agreement with each other and, with a bit of luck, Scotland could Remain MPs.Although the Scottish Greens are part of the couplersquos plan, Patrick Harviersquos party did not stand in any of the thirteen seats at the last general election.:SNP failed to attract any large cash donations in Dolan is a respected figure in the SNP whose views are listened to in the upper echelons of the party. He was an early backer of the SNP supporting a second Brexit referendum at a time when the party was lukewarm on the policy. Sturgeon changed her mind after his intervention.Fryer is a Lib Dem member and has never voted SNP.A spokesperson for the Scottish Liberal Democrats said: "The problem with that idea is that the SNP use every vote at every election to advance independence. They wont ever drop it, even when faced with something as serious as Brexit. It is the main thing they care about."It would be irresponsible for the economy of Scotland to give the SNP a helping hand. They would pile chaos on chaos."Scottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoThis is a desperate move from parties still rattled from the last General Election. These parties should be comfortable enough in their own skin to fight on their own terms.

title: scottish-labour-registers-lowest-level-income-nearly-two-decades
story: The ailing party, which slumped to fth place at the European election, saw its income fall by over % compared to the previous year and and registered a pound, deficit.Meanwhile, the infighting that broke out last week over the partyrsquos position on another independence referendum has intensied after a party peer effectively called for Jeremy Corbynrsquos shadow Scottish secretary to be replaced.Lord Foulkes, a former minister, said ldquoalmost anyone would be better in the post than MP Lesley Laird.Civil war broke out in Scottish Labour on Tuesday after shadow chancellor John McDonnell said in Edinburgh that a Corbyn-led Government would not block indyref.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationThis stance directly contradicted Leonard ndash a fellow left-winger ndash and led to claims that UK Labour had overruled the Scottish party.Tensions escalated on Friday after it emerged that Scottish Labour general secretary Brian Roy had been forced out of his job. One of his potential successors is Tommy Kane, who advises Corbyn on Scotland.The partyrsquos latest accounts reveal that Scottish Labour is also facing financial problems.According to the Electoral Commission, the party brought in pound, in , which covers Leonardrsquos first full year in charge.This contrasts with pound, in , pound, in , pound,, twelve months earlier, pound, during the year of the independence referendum, and pound, in .Records go back to  and the  figure is the lowest for any of the  years.Donation income in Leonardrsquos first year also fell to pound, from pound, in . The figure was the lowest since .However, membership and subscription income was up from pound, to pound, and the party has a six-figure reserve.:Scottish Labour breaks silence over anti-semitism investigation by blasting "biased" BBCA Scottish Labour spokesperson said: " was the first year since  that Scottish Labour hadnt been fighting either an election or a referendum campaign."Unlike the Tories were not a party backed by and for big businesses and millionaires, were proud of being a people-powered movement funded by lots of smaller donations and trade union members."However, a party source said: "This financial decline is alarming and will panic candidates preparing for a snap election. Sadly its no surprise given our complete failure to engage with the business community that donations have dried up, and we look more unelectable by the day."Meanwhile, sources told this newspaper that Roy was forced out because he could not be relied on to help push through changes that are important to Leonard and the Corbynistas.It is understood that, during a recent attempt at hiring a new head of communications, Leonardrsquos team wanted the job to go to a journalist from a far-left publication, but Roy resisted.Leonardrsquos allies also want the partyrsquos governing executive to appoint some candidates for the Holyrood elections in , rather than letting members decide. An insider said Roy would have raised questions about such a move.In another development, Foulkes criticised McDonnellrsquos comments on indyref and blasted what he regards as the shadow cabinetrsquos failure to develop UK-wide policies on constitutional change.ldquoI have been trying to tell them for four years, but b****r all has been done about it, he said.On Lairdrsquos role in Corbynrsquos team, he said: ldquoShe approached me and said she had heard a rumour that I was not a great fan of hers. I said the rumour is true. Almost anyone would be better than her.On Leonard, he said: ldquoHe has no charisma and no leadership credentials at all.Leonardrsquos MSPs were split last week on whether to sign a statement condemning McDonnell, with the majority agreeing and a minority refusing.The MSP group meets tomorrow in Glasgow for an away day, an event geared towards fostering camaraderie and team-building.

title: snp-veteran-wings-scotland-plan-new-party-quot-split-quot-pro-indy-vote
story: Jim Sillars, the former depute leader of the SNP, said that a suggestion by Wings over Scotland author Stuart Campbell for another party to stand on the List could make it harder to win a pro-independence majority in .However, he said: ldquoThis is a sign of frustration on the part of people in the independence movement, which I fully understand.The  Holyrood election is shaping up to be a single issue poll on whether the SNP and Greens can secure a majority of seats for another independence referendum.Former Sturgeon adviser: SNP and Lib Dems should unite to wipe out the ToriesThe two parties won  seats at the last Holyrood election, but the UK Government has consistently rejected another plebiscite in the current term.Holyroodrsquos electoral system means that a party which performs well in the first past the postseats will find it harder to make gains on the eight regional Lists. In , the SNP won  FPTP seats, but only secured four List members.Bath-based Campbell, whose Wings over Scotland describes itself as a "Scottish political media digest and monitor", has been criticised for his attacks on opponents of independence.He also lost a defamation case to former Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale, who had accused him of sending "homophobic tweets".It was reported yesterday that Campbell has been discussing an idea for a new pro-independence party, which would contest the  election.He said: ldquoItrsquos conceivable that a Wings party might be able to pick up list seats that the pro-indy side otherwise might not."The plan could be pushed ahead with ldquo it looked like there wasnrsquot going to be a pro-independence majority, which I think is a very real danger.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationOne senior SNP source said that such a party could,the SNP focused solely on FPTP, win around  List seats, thus securing a pro-independence majority.However Sillars, who is one of his partyrsquos most famous figures, said: ldquoIf you set up a party that seeks to take votes away from the SNP, which presumably they are trying to do, then you make it harder to get the overall majority at Holyrood.He added that, far from the SNP repeating its success in FPTP constituencies, Nicola Sturgeonrsquos party could lose some of these seats in  and need List pick-ups: ldquoPerhaps nobody has thought that the SNP might need more people from the List than last time. You might fall between two stools. A bit of patience is required in the independence movement. Whatrsquos two or three or four years in the le of the nation He warned: ldquoI think it possibly could split the vote. It could end up a mess.Sillars is a critic of the SNP leadership, but noted: ldquoWe have one instrument, the SNP, and the fact of the matter is that that is the instrument we need to get independence.The Wings over Scotland blog stated yesterday: "As wersquove said, itrsquos only a half-formed thought at the moment. Wersquove sounded out a few people for opinions and feelings, and in some cases asked themthey might in principle consider running for it, but thatrsquos as far as itrsquos gone."

title: mind-business-china-tells-dominic-raab-hong-kong-call
story: Mr Raab spoke with Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam and stressed the need for ldquomeaningful political dialogue, and a fully independent investigation into recent events as a way to build trust in the territory.The former British colony has been the site of widespread protests in recent months which began with a campaign against a controversial extradition bill and has gone on to include a push for electoral reforms in the Chinese territory.Hua Chunying, a spokeswoman for the Chinese foreign ministry, said the days where Britain ruled Hong Kong were ldquolong gone.She told reporters: ldquoThe UK has no sovereignty, jurisdiction or right of supervision over Hong Kong.ldquoAffairs of Hong Kong brook no foreign interference.ldquoIt is simply wrong for the British government to directly call Hong Kongrsquos Chief Executive to exert pressure.ldquoThe Chinese side seriously urges the UK to stop its interference in Chinarsquos internal affairs and stop making random and inflammatory accusations on Hong Kong.Protesters raised the old British colonial flag in the Hong Kong legislative chamber on the nd anniversary of the territoryrsquosto Chinese rule as part of the protests.Police used tear gas against activists who had occupied the legislative council building and painted pro-democracy slogans on the walls.The territoryrsquos leader, Carrie Lam, condemned the ldquoextreme use of violence and vandalism by protesters.Speaking about the call between Mr Raab and Ms Lam on Friday, a spokesman for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office said: ldquoThe Foreign Secretary underlined the strength of the relationship between the UK and Hong Kong, noting our support for Hong Kongrsquos high degree of autonomy as provided for in the Joint Declaration and our commitment to the principle of lsquoOne country, Two systemsrsquo.ldquoThe Foreign Secretary condemned violent acts by all sides but emphasised the right to peaceful protest, noting that hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong people had chosen this route to express their views.ldquoHe underlined that the violence should not cloud the lawful actions of the majority.

title: patch-plant-hotel-broken-easyjet-seat-39-text-door-39-neighbours
story: "Perhaps I could make a spa appointment on your behalf  If you dont mind me saying, you do look a little wilted in places. One of our hydration treatments should perk you right up. How about a bite to eat  Todays special is a seaweed-infused tomato feed hellip"Plants, you see, are all the rage. To clary, Im not talking about the sort that you ndash allegedly ndash get in the audience on BBC Question Time. Nor the kind used by TV evangelists, psychics and other charlatans of that ilk. I mean the botanical iety with roots, stems, leaves and flowers.The worlds first plant hotel opened its doors last week with the idea likened to taking a dog or cat to a boarding kennel when you head off on holiday. Except at the Patch Plant Hotel in London, general manager Rose Growerpromises that your beloved houseplants will be well cared for.I dont speak fluent millennial, but it seems plants are the new pugs. For a start, they are photogenic which means they look good on Instagram. Also, when you are struggling to get on the property ladder and your landlord says no to pets, you can always assemble a jungle of houseplants instead.If you happen to be a plant reading this , it does sound like you are in for a treat.Susan Swarbrick: Nessie sightings on the rise and the perils of Angry Birds eyebrowsI would, however, urge caution. Perhaps akin to the Hotel Calornia, you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave. You wait patiently but your owner fails toand collect you. Were they in a terrible potting shed accident  Kidnapped by Alan Titchmarsh  Eaten by an overzealous Venus flytrap Or did they visit Patch ndash the online plant retailer which coined the idea for the hotel ndash and pick out a funkier replacement  Which is a roundabout way of saying: nice PR gimmick.Back ache in the skiesAIR travel has its challenges at the best of times. From playing check-in roulette with the luggage scales to the woes of navigating security .Then theres duty free where you feel like Indiana Jones rolling under the closing door in the Temple of Doom as you attempt to dodge fragrance spritzers, trays piled high with samples of expensive chocolates and racks of tourist tat such as gaudy tea towels and thimbles.Next, you must schlep for miles to reach the gate. The distance from check-in to the gate is always inversely proportional to the time available to get there. If you are five hours early, you will be at gate one. Only  minutes until the flight departs  Youll be at gate .Finally, once on board the plane, all you want to do is sink into your seat and decompress. Spare a thought, then, for the passenger taking an easyJet flight from Luton to Geneva last week who found her seat had no back upon which to rest her weary, airport-beleaguered shoulders.The airline insists that the broken seat was not in use and waiting to be repaired , yet one cant help but fear a seed has been planted. Ryanair must be furious they didnt think of it first.Love thy neighbour EVERYBODY needs good neighbours ndash or so the Australian television soap opera theme tune goes. But what about "text door" neighbours In the latest chapter of an evermore unwieldy tome titled The Internet: Daft Things Sheeple Do, folk are sending text messages to mobile phone numbers with the last digit one numeral higher or lower than their own.The idea is thatyour phone number ends in , then your so-called text door neighbours number ends in  or . In a nutshell: people are initiating conversations with strangers based on the random allocation of a series of numbers.The viral trend started in  and has seen a resurgence recently, with users sharing their exchanges on Twitter. Results range from striking up a friendly rapport to being told in no uncertain terms to get lost.Susan Swarbrick: Nessie sightings on the rise and the perils of Angry Birds eyebrowsGranted, some of the interactions are funny but I dont see the appeal. If you have that much time on your hands, why not put it to good use by popping in to visit an elderly neighbour or volunteering at a community project  Forge a real human connection with those around you. Imagine that.

title: chinese-authorities-no-mood-compromise
story: HE is well known for his tough style of leadership. Doubtless thatrsquos why on Friday the Chinese government brought former deputy police commissioner Alan Lau Yip-shing out of retirement, in a move that is said to have ldquostunned Hong Hongrsquos law enforcement community.While serving as commissioner it was Lau who, back in , oversaw operations when protesters demanding greater democracy occupied key roads for  straight days.In , it was Lau who also took charge of the crackdown on illegal hawkers in the cityrsquos busy Mong Kok district sparking riots that were also seen to be politically motivated and became widely known as the ldquoFishball Revolution.Once again it seems the senior policeman with the ldquohands on reputation has been brought in to quell political dissent on Hong Kongrsquos streets.Laursquos appointment on ldquospecial duty came as the cityrsquos embattled police force geared up for three days of sit-in protests at Hong Kong International Airport, starting from Friday and culminating today.However, no-one for a moment believes that it will mark the end of almost nine weeks of anti-government rallies that have frequently ended in violent clashes with police.What began as a movement against an extradition bill, which would have let criminal suspects in Hong Kong be handed over for trial by communist party-controlled courts in mainland China, has since evolved into the biggest challenge from dissenters since the Tiananmen protests  years ago that still reverberate to this day.Today, just like back then, the appointment of veteran chief police officer Alan Lau Yip-shing indicates that the Chinese authorities are in no mood for compromise.That much was made clear by an official from the Chinese governmentrsquos Hong Kong office, who last week warned, ldquowe would like to make clear to the very small group of unscrupulous and violent criminals and the dirty forces behind them: those who play with fire will perish by it.In that one statement lie clues to much of the fear, paranoia and disinformation that have been the hallmark of this latest crisis in Hong Kong.To begin with, far from being the work of a small group, hundreds of thousands of ordinary people have taken to the cityrsquos streets, eventhose numbers have dwindled of late.Reports of alleged criminal involvement suggest that rather than such malign forces lurking within the ranks of the protesters, itrsquos perhaps been the Chinese authorities which have deployed Triad gang members to do their violent bidding in Hong Kong.Last month, a large group of masked men carrying wooden sticks and iron rods began attacking protesters, journalists and passengers indiscriminately at the cityrsquos Yuen Long MTR railway station leaving scores injured.It later came to light that some of the attackers were indeed triad members and were known to senior pro-establishment politician Junius Ho Kwan-yiu.ldquoThe thugs who carried out the Yuen Long attacks have only served to convince the public that triad societies are a dangerous resource available to those wishing to engage them, wrote Justin Bong-Kwan in the South China Morning Postin the wake of the attacks.Like other observers he points out that Hong Kong triads have a long history of political involvement and "thugs for hire" is nothing new.Back in , when deputy police commissioner Alan Lau Yip-shing was tasked with policing the violence during the Occupy protests, unknown gangs from neighbouring Guangdong province in China staged a similar attack at a night market, beating up protesters.Commenting on the current situation, Lynette H Ong, a China expert at the University of Toronto, says that ldquothugs for hire offer an expedient strategy to intimidate protesters and allow authorities to skirt responsibility for any violence that may take place. ldquoShort of rolling in tanks, outsourced violence arguably may be the most effective means to ward off protesters, wrote Ong recently in the Washington Post.Not that anyone has ruled out the possibility of troop deployment should the crisis deepen.But would China really send in the Peoplersquos Liberation Armyand deploy tanks on Hong Kongrsquos streets should the situation worsen A recent propaganda video from the Chinese armyrsquos Hong Kong garrison showing troops quelling civil unrest along with a similar large-scale police drill just across the mainland border were hardly subtle in their messaging.In one scene, a soldier is seen shouting ldquoAll consequences are at your own risk! as protesters are seen retreating before a phalanx of troops. Comments from officials and state media denouncing the protesters as ldquocriminals, crossing ldquoredlines through ldquointolerable violence along with the oppressive nature of the Beijing regime and the communist partyrsquos willingness to use force, must linger in the minds of many who take to Hong Kongrsquos streets.It all adds to the perception that Beijing wants to convey and never fails to repeatedly remind the public that Hong Kong law allows for PLA troops to ldquoassistrequested by the cityrsquos government.Many people in Hong Kong believe that the territoryrsquos leader Carrie Lam has become a lame duck as the political crisis has spiralled, with Beijing now fully calling the shots from behind the scenes. Lam has rarely been seen in public in recent weeks and at her most recent appearance was flanked by a number of colleagues.But despite Beijingrsquos ability to call things as it sees it, most analysts or indeed Hong Kong people themselves believe that the chances of PLA soldiers leaving their barracks for deployment on the streets soon are slim.They point to the fact that Hong Kong still has  years to go of its One Country, Two Systems whereby it transitions from its British past to its Chinese future while allowing freedoms unheard of on the mainland.ldquoItrsquos a political problem, I donrsquot think sending in a security force would effectively deal with it, was how Adam Ni, a Chinese military researcher at Macquarie University summed it up to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation recently.Analysts also say Chinarsquos deeply strained relations with Western nations, particularly the US, would also act as a retraining factor on president Xi Jinpingrsquos regime in Beijing.But this has not stopped Chinese officials and Communist Party media insisting that Western ldquoblack hands and a US covert role are behind the protests.On Thursday and Friday, Beijing-backed media outlets circulated a photograph of Julie Eadeh, the political unit chief of the US consulate general in Hong Kong, meeting in a hotel lobby with prominent members of the opposition, including -year-old Joshua Wong, a key figure in the protests that rocked Hong Kong five years ago.Chinese State broadcaster CCTV has also insisted that the Central Intelligence Agencywas known for instigating ldquocolour revolutions, a reference to demonstrations that sprang up in former Soviet states during the previous decade.Beijing officials also said this week that the Hong Kong unrest had the markings of a colour revolution.According to Steve Tsang, director of the China Institute at the School of Oriental and African studiesUniversity of London, the propaganda attacks represented a classic Communist Party influence effort to shore up public opinion in Hong Kong.ldquoThat is exactly what they would call the United Front approach. We would call it ide and rule, Tsang said, referring to the Communist Party wing that is responsible for political influence campaigns in China and abroad.ldquoThey want to isolate the protesters from the bulk of the Hong Kong population and say, lsquoThis is all about foreign interference,rsquo Tsang told the Washington Post.Beijingrsquos relationship with with Hong Kong and its people has always been an evolving one. Seen even from a purely economic perspective Chinarsquos attitude has changed considerably in recent times.At the time of the handover in , the territoryrsquos economy was equivalent to nearly one-fth of Chinarsquos. Today the figure is %, and Hong Kongrsquos port is far less important in shipping goods from the mainland.China is simply no longer as directly dependent on the territory for its economic welfare as it once was, when foreign firms operating from Hong Kong, managerial expertise and access to international markets via its port were critical.For the moment such wider economic concerns and geopolitics will have little bearing on the day-to-day running of the protests still taking place on Hong Kongrsquos streets after two months.While the absolute number of protesters has fallen from an estimated two million who marched, largely peacefully, on June  to , strikers, they continue to be thorn in the side of the authorities. Much has been made of the remarkable and often ingenious tactics they have adopted in confronting the police.Almost daily thousands have adopted what has been described as near ldquoguerrilla tactics that often involve a series of ldquoflash mob events designed to distract and confuse the authorities.ldquoOur aim is not to let the police arrest us. We need to be like water, one protester was quoted as saying while on the streets last week.ldquoBe water, my friend ndash a take on a famous Bruce Lee quote to be ldquoformless, shapeless, like water ndash has been a rallying cry of the leaderless movement.The fluid tactics of the black-clad vanguard of protesters mean donrsquot gather in one place, where you can be encircled donrsquot have clear leaders who can be arrested ebb and flow the demonstrations to keep officials confused. Many carry laser pointers to "shoot" at public security cameras to disable them such is the fear of being identied and arrested.Almost all of those who now come on to the streets are equipped with helmets, goggles and gas masks to ward off the more than , rounds of tear gas fired over the nine weeks of protest.Hong Kongersrsquo experience of resistance has made the protests sharply effective.ldquoProtesters experience these illegal protests the same way soldiers often describe war -long periods of boredom punctuated by terrying episodes of violence, wrote Trey Menefee, a Hong Kong-based social scientist in Foreign Policy magazine around the time the current protests began.ldquoThe key is to determine when the police will move, where theyrsquoll come from, and what tactics theyrsquoll likely use. Most protesters have learned from experience the importance of knowing when to fall back and not to get caught somewhere without a predetermined exit route, Menefee explained.Many observers of events on the streets say the willingness of some protesters to fight back in the face of police violence is a marked contrast to the ldquoextremely well-behaved, peaceful Umbrella Movement of , when students occupied public spaces and streets outside regional government offices for  days.ldquoThis time there are no leaders. Just anonymous people, groups of friends, civil society and an army of volunteers organising everything: medics, food and drinks, all kind of anti-riot protective gear, volunteers to drive protesters late at night, says Gallego Abellan, a video and photojournalist who spoke with the online US-based portal The Intercept.ldquoPeople leave money in the machines that sell subway tickets for those that canrsquot pay, volunteers bring clothes so people can change after the demonstration and not be identied as protesters."Therersquos even a group of mothers that help those youth involved in the protest that need any kind of assistance, explains Abellan.Yesterday, the ersity of those making up the protesters ranks was once again visible on the streets with some arriving back at Hong Kongrsquos airport a day after a peaceful gathering there of about , activists.Hundreds occupied the arrivals hall yesterday, some of them sitting on the floor drawing protest posters, while others politely greeted arriving passengers.In the morning, in two separate protests, small groups of elderly Hong Kongers and families marched near the financial centrersquos business district.Both marches unlike many of the rallies of late were peaceful. Few doubt things will remain that way for long though.In less than a fortnightrsquos time those on the streets will surpass rsquos -day Umbrella Movement democracy protests. While those protests had largely fizzled out by the end, there are few signs of the same happening this time around with the movement remaining fiery and determined.What ultimately they will achieve remains to be seen, butone thing is certain itrsquos that Hong Kong politically will never be the same again.The recalling of tough former deputy police commissioner Alan Lau Yip-shing out of retirement to deal with the situation, might just be an ominous sign of things to come.

title: love-living-edinburgh-festival-time
story: But donrsquot believe the hype or the viral tweets. Irsquom Edinburgh born and bred ndash and I love it. How can you not Walking around the buzzing streets of the Old Town, I still get a kick out of watching tourists hold up the traffic as they rub Greyfriars Bobbyrsquos nose or take shedloads of selfies in front of the cafe where JK Rowling wrote the first Harry Potter novel. Irsquom more than happy to politely point them in the direction of the castle or down the mound, watching their bemused faces as I explain what seems obvious to me but confusing to them, that Edinburgh is built on two levels.Even when the weather is a bit miserable, Irsquove found myself halfway down the Royal Mile, standing as part of a huge circle of people from all over the world, captivated by an Australian street performer. It may be pouring with rain and wersquove all got wet feet but together wersquore laughing and clapping as a small, unsuspecting child is roped in to the finale.Itrsquos fun to walk where I spent my school days mucking about with my pals with the advantage of knowing where to duck and e, find the stillness among the madness, or take the short cut that is technically a long cut, but takes less time because no-one  knows to go that way. As I eavesdrop on the conversations of tourists gushing in  languages over how beautul the ancient spires are, I smile to myself with a sense of pride, almost asI built the Old Town with my own hands.Edinburgh is magical all the time but the transformation it undertakes to become the worldrsquos biggest arts playground really is something , and I get a kick out of seeing how the city comes together as old buildings change into unrecognisable pop-up theatres and bars.The financials are pretty transformative too, of course. Attracting an audience of more that . million, the Edinburgh Festivals bring in pound million to the Scottish economy each year, a substantial proportion of the tourist revenue for Scotland. It also accounts for more than , jobs in the ever-competitive creative industries.Thatrsquos not to say everything is hunky dory, of course, and more voices than ever before are highlighting the other side of the cityrsquos success. I have personal experience, too. During my time at the University of Edinburgh, it was the standard to be forced out of your student flat during August, replaced by festival visitors willing to pay two monthrsquos rent and more for just one week.Two years after graduating I am still living at home with my mother because Edinburgh rents remain so incredibly expensive, with long-term residents and renters priced out in favour of short-term holiday lets. There are reported to be a staggering , short-term lets in the city, more than half of Scotlandrsquos total in a city of under ,. One in  homes in the city centre are thought to be holiday lets.I understand a proposed tourist tax is controversial, but it already exists in many European cities and would provide a welcome financial boost to infrastructure. It would perhaps also encourage visitors to treat the city with a bit more care, perhaps refraining from urinating in public and leaving their rubbish on our streets and on public transport.During these times of political and social uncertainty, the arts remain a vital way to entertain, bring people together and celebrate the world around us. As someone who grew up and went to school in the north of Edinburgh, next to some of the most deprived areas in Scotland, the Festival can leave some residents feeling a bit like visitors in their own home.Year on year the Festival has grown, and it has been nice to see it spill out from the Royal Mile and southside areas towards the New Town and Leith. This allows the small, local and independent business outside the central area to profit from the cityrsquos extra footfall.For local communities, even with a venue now on your doorstep, ticket prices average at about pound-pound, which would set a family of four back at least pound, a disposable income that is only available to those in more affluent areas.I would feel less annoyedthe performers and artists themselves were profiting from the ticket prices. The Festival, particularly the Fringe, is seen as a rite of passage for those who want to pursue a long-term career in the arts. Many arrive in Edinburgh, excited and energised, hopeful for a career-defining review, often self-funded or with some financial support in the form of a grant or bursary. They do not expect to make a profit. They often make a loss, with the venues and promoters raking it in.Many, many people make this festival happen. Most are young and keen, and get little financial reward for their graft. Itrsquos not unusual to sign a contract that means it is legal for them to only have one day off a week during the month of August, with others putting in -hour days at venues infor a pass that allows them to see shows for free.When you consider the legacy of what the Festival was meant to achieve when it was set up more than  years ago, it leaves a bittersweet taste in your mouth. Thatrsquos not to say there arenrsquot positive developments, of course, especially on the ersity front.This year, an initiative called Fringe of Colour, established by Edinburgh University student Jess Brough, has partnered with venues to provide tickets to local people of colour under  to see shows that feature performers of colour, an attempt to fight back against the lack of racial ersity in both performers and audiences.The Edinburgh International Book Festival, meanwhile, is offering a ldquopay what you can option for some of its events and free alternatives can also be found in the Book Fringe and Free Fringe.Despite my frustrations, I love the Festival for the culture, fun and good energy it brings to my city in August. I couldnrsquot imagine being anywhere . After all, where  would you experience such amazing things Just the other night I watched a trans, non-binary person of colour, Travis Alabanza, take up space on the stage of the Traverse Theatre, with the spectacular Burgerz. The night before, I sat in the front row at Edinburgh Universtiyrsquos Bedlam Theatre to watch Splintered, a cabaret about being queer and Caribbean.I felt proud of both of these performances for challenging an audience that tends to be white, middle-class and incredibly privileged.Last year, I saw a group of Australian men performing burlesque cabaret in a building that was originally built as a college for the Free Church of Scotland.You canrsquot get that in Glasgow, can you  Not yet.Keep your sanity and avoid the crowds this Festival If yoursquore in among the madness, grab a coffee from Thomas J Walls on Forrest Road. From the street it may look busy but the cafeacute goes quite far back and there is a good chance yoursquoll be able to snag one of the sofas, close your eyes and pretend yoursquore anywhere but Edinburgh. Wander down Leith Walk for a drink at one of the many pubs or bars without an Oxbridge accent in range. Smoke  Mirrors on Constitution Street is a favourite. Get some fresh air by climbing Arthurrsquos seat or Calton Hill, the latter being a much easier walk and offering a better view. Yoursquoll be able to see how busy and beautul the city is without being right in it. If it all really gets too much, leave the city and go west. Trains to Glasgow run frequently and take less than an hour from Waverly station. But no, Irsquom not telling you where you can get a pint for pound. ndash thatrsquos a secret for Edinburgh locals only!

title: 80-years-wizard-oz
story: ORIGINSBEFORE the Munchkin orgies, before the director slapped Judy Garland, before the Wicked Witch nearly burned to death, The Wizard of Oz was a day-dream in the mind of a two-time loser called L Frank Baum.Baum was born rich but flunked most things he tried - his store lsquoBaumrsquos Bazaarrsquo, and a newspaper he ran, both failed. However, he loved children, and he loved writing. Baum wanted a daughter - he planned to call her Dorothy - but when his first child Frank was born in , Baum began inventing stories to entertain him, stories which would eventually be published as The Wonderful Wizard of Oz in August , with  sequels following.Baum was unsuccessfully adapting his Oz stories into films in the early years of Hollywood when he died at his home, Ozcot, in Calornia in . Twenty years later, in , Hollywood would finally work its magic on Baumrsquos creation and turn The Wizard of Oz into the most celebrated and influential film in cinema history.This week the movie marks its th anniversary. For a film which moulded the childhoods of millions, the story of how this strange fairytale came to the screen is far from kid-friendly. In fact, at times, itrsquos strictly for adults only.THE STUDIOIN , Louis B Mayer, the mogul who headed -Goldwyn-Mayer, the most glittering of Hollywoodrsquos dream factories, bought the rights to The Wizard of Oz for ,. The plan was to make a movie rivalling Disneyrsquos game-changing Snow White. MGM marked Oz lsquoProduction Number rsquo. It cost nearly m to make and was one of the most expensive productions ever, taking nearly  years to turn a profit. The filmrsquos lyricist, Yip Harburg, said the studio never banked on Oz making money: lsquoOnce a year they did a loser for prestige.In the s, the studio system ran Hollywood. Directors, writers, and actors were all lsquoownedrsquo by one of the big studios like MGM or Columbia. Studio bosses had final say, and below them the producer was king, not the director. Writers were told what movies to work on, as were directors and actors.Herman Mankiewicz, whorsquod go on to win an Oscar for Citizen Kane, was the first of ten writers attached to Oz. An alcoholic, his major contribution was the idea that the film should be shot in black and white when Dorothy is in Kansas, but in colour when shersquos in Oz. The American poet Ogden Nash stepped in briefly after Mankiewicz was taken off the project, but it was third writer Noel Langley, aged just , who made the script his own, and created much of the story, including the ruby slippers - although they were originally silver. However, he also had sprawling side stories involving the Wicked Witchrsquos son lsquoBulborsquo, which were later cut.Summer leaves: Scotlandrsquos top writers select their favourite literary fragmentsLangley, however, would see his career ruined by studio boss Mayer. After shooting ended, Langley was heard to publicly say: ldquoEvery time Mayer smiles at me, I feel a snake has crawled over my foot. He was blacklisted and couldnrsquot get another job for any studio.Langley watched the movie alone in a cinema on Hollywood Bouled when it was released. ldquoI sat and cried like a bloody child, he said. ldquoI loathed the picture. He wasnrsquot alone. The New Yorker called it a ldquostinkeroo. As Aljean Harmetz says in her book The Making of The Wizard of Oz: ldquoMost of the serious critics thought it dreadful.THE MUSICThe wrong man got the Oscar. When Oz won the Academy Award for Best Original Score it went to Herbert Stothart - house composer for MGM. The only problem was he hadnrsquot written any of the songs - the real work was done by lyricist and composer Yip Harburg and Harold Arlen. But under the studio system jobbing songwriters were treated as badly as jobbing screenwriters.Arlen and Harburg - later blacklisted as a communist during the McCarthy era - were paid a flat rate of , and given a bungalow at MGM to live and work in. Their first task was tackling ldquothe lemon drop songs - light, catchy tunes like Ding Dong the Witch is Dead and Wersquore Off to See the Wizard. Some tunes, like If I Only Had a Brain, had already been written for other musicals and just needed new lyrics.The idea for the filmrsquos anthem, Somewhere Over the Rainbow, came to Arlen when he drove past Schwabrsquos Drugstore on Sunset Bouled - a place that summed up the songrsquos sense of longing. The drugstore was famous for the wannabe movie stars who hung out there, and the legend that a beautul girl could get an agent before she finished her milkshake at the soda fountain.After his first preview of the movie, though, Mayer pulled Over the Rainbow from the film asking: ldquoWhy does she sing in a barnyard . Harburg and Arlan were horried. Harburg said the studio bosses were ldquoignorant jerks. Eventually, Mayer relented and allowed the song to remain. Other songs were not so fortunate - The Jitterbug took five weeks to shoot and cost pound, but ended up on the cutting room floor for the first release.As the filmrsquos biographer Aljean Harmetz says: ldquoWhat is most remarkable about the Wizard of Oz - and perhaps the mark of its success - is that one doesnrsquot really think of it as a musical.THE STARSMGM was famous for having ldquomore stars than there are in heaven. Judy Garland was one of  actors under contract with the studio when she was hired in , aged , on  a week. It was the beginning of a career which would bring Garland fame and adoration, as well as abject mental and physical suffering. She was a raw and sensational talent but not conventionally beautul, and in the Hollywood of the s that meant ldquothe teeth capped, the nose restructured, the thick waist held in by corsets, and the body reshaped as well as possible by diet and massage - as Aljean Harmetz describes how Mayer moulded his young star.The mogul even referred to Garland as his ldquolittle hunchback. He initially didnrsquot want her in Oz and tried to secure Shirley Temple, but she was under contract with th Century Fox. The trials and humiliations of child stardom led to a letime struggle with drink and drugs for Garland - eventually leading to her death, after a number of suicide attempts, by an accidental barbiturate overdose aged .Ray Bolger, Bert Lahr and Jack Haley - who played the Scarecrow, Cowardly Lion and Tin Man - were all seasoned vaudeville stars on higher salaries than Garland. Bolger was on  a week. Haley was a last minute replacement. Initially, Buddy Ebsen - who went on to star in the The Beverly Hillbillies - was cast as the Tin Man, but an allergy to aluminium make-up nearly killed him, and Haley stepped in.WC Fields was the first call for playing the Wizard - but he wanted too much cash, asking pound,, so Frank Morgan begged the studio for the role. Morgan was not a star, but a charming alcoholic. He carried a briefcase filled with Martinis so he was never without a drink. In an astonishing coincidence, a frock coat bought from a second hand store for Morganrsquos costume was found with a label stitched inside - it read lsquoL Frank Baumrsquo, and was authenticated as the writerrsquos. When shooting wrapped, Morgan gave the coat to Baumrsquos widow.The Wicked Witch might have turned out very dferentproducer Mervyn Le Roy had his way - he wanted a glamorous villainess, all sequins and figure-hugging dresses. Studio bosses scotched the idea, and the role fell to Margaret Hamilton who made the part her own.Hamilton was a -year-old single mother who, although shersquos terried generations of children, is recalled by all who knew her as a kind, gentle, clever and funny woman. Playing the Good Witch Glinda was Billie Burke, the bejewelled we of Florenz Ziegfield, of Ziegfield Follies fame. When her husband died leaving her half a million in debt, Burke turned to the movies to stay afloat. Burkersquos dressing room had satin walls and a pink chaise-longue, Hamiltonrsquos was a canvas tent.:Brian Cox on bringing Logan Roy and Succession home to ScotlandThere was one final star to cast: Toto - played by Terry, a female Cairn Terrier, who suffered from chronic shyness. Despite a tendency to hide when there was loud noises, Terry was hired on pound a week. By that stage of her career, -year-old Garland was on pound.THE MUNCHKINSldquoWe had a hell of a time with those little guys, producer Mervyn LeRoy recalled. ldquoThey got into sex orgies at the hotel. We had to have police on every floor hellip Everything you can imagine sexually was going on.Screenwriter Noel Langley remembers ldquoshowgirls being escorted to their rooms by armed guards. Judy Garland once said: ldquoThey were drunks. They got smashed every night and the police had to pick them up in butterfly nets.Others described the Munchkins as an ldquounholy assemblage of pimps, hookers, and gamblers.One Munchkin actor bit a policeman, a few were known to carry knives, and some female Munchkin actors did solicit the crew. But as the filmrsquos biographer Aljean Harmetz says most were well-behaved. ldquoMemories are distorted because the activities of [a] few hellip were applied to all the Munchkins.In fact, many - whorsquod been exploited and abused due to their disabilities - were shy and vulnerable. This was the era when most of the  little people needed for the film could be hired from a company called lsquoSingerrsquos Midgetsrsquo, on five dollars a day.The lsquobig worldrsquo was also dangerous. Attendants were hired to take some to the bathroom after one actor fell down a toilet and couldnrsquot get out.SHOOTINGOz had four directors. Richard Thorpe for two weeks, George Cukor for three days, and King Vidor for ten days - but it was Victor Fleming who got the credit and put in the most work over four months. Fleming also took the Best Picture Oscar from Oz with his other film of  Gone With the Wind.Fleming was macho to the bone. He shot wild cats outside his Bel Air home, and had a particularly vile party trick of killing flies and eating them. He was a flamboyant anti-communist with his own plane, and infamous for womanising. During one confrontation on set, Fleming lost his temper with Garland who was unable to stop laughing at the clowning of Lahrrsquos Lion.John Lee Mahin, a screenwriter friend of Fleming who was on set, recalled: ldquoThey must have done the scene ten times and eventually she was giggling so much she got hysterical. She couldnrsquot stop laughing. And Vic slapped her on the face. lsquoAll right now,rsquo he said, lsquogo back to your dressing room.rsquo She went. And when she came back she said, lsquoOk.rsquo And they did the scene.The shooting was exhausting and gruelling - especially for the Lion, Tin Man and Scarecrow who suffered through y make-up sessions and baking arc lights. By lunchtime, with their make-up melting, the crew found them so ldquodisgusting to look at that the three ate alone in their dressing room.Garlandrsquos breasts were bound with cloth to keep her looking pre-pubescent, causing her considerable pain, but she never complained. Many of the crew worked round the clock and the place was awash in alcohol.Filming was plagued by accidents - thanks to the demanding and physical special effects. Betty Danko, stunt double for Margaret Hamilton, was crushed on set. Hamilton was badly injured when she caught fire during a scene where the witch disappears in a puff of smoke. Her face was burned and the skin on one hand completely removed, exposing the nerves. She was unable to film for six weeks. When she ed, Fleming grasped her so hard by the injured hand that she almost fainted.LEGACYAlthough the film has earned billions to date, it initially made a loss of about m at the box office. However, its real legacy isnrsquot financial but cultural. Its simple message of family, hope and home caught the imagination of a public about to face six years of war in Europe. Its arrival on TV at Christmas from the s to the s secured its place in the hearts of babyboomers and Generation Xers. The gay community embraced Garland as a suffering icon.Director David Lynch once said Oz influenced every film made since . His own movie Wild At Heart is a love letter to Oz. Steven Spielbergrsquos AI is Oz reimagined with robots. Musicians have been inspired by it, like Elton John with Goodbye Yellow Brick Road. If therersquos a list of all time great movies, Oz is there, usually at the top. Its words and symbols, songs and ideas are weaved into everyday le. How often do you hear someone say lsquoWersquore not in Kansas anymorersquo, or refer to a villain as lsquothe Wicked Witch of the Westrsquo. The Wizard of Oz has shaped our imaginations from childhood to adulthood - which is why even at the ripe old age of  it will continue to live on long after all of us have quit the stage.Ray Bolger the Scarecrow said it was the moviersquos ldquosimple philosophy which made it immortal: ldquoTherersquos no place like home, everybody has a heart, everybody has a brain, everybody has a soul.

title: piping-glasgow-plays-part-hosts-world-championships
story: More than  pipe bands will be taking part,  of whom will be fighting for the supreme title. Not forgetting the Highland dancers, also competing for their top world award.One of the other nations competing to claim the origin of the pipes is Ireland. The reigning world champions ndash The Field Marshal Montgomery Pipe Band ndash hail from Lisburn in the northern part of the island. They arenrsquot just defending their title but can lay claim to being the most successful band of all time, with  Worlds and innumerable other titles. But before the main course, therersquos the entreacutee, the dozens of events organised by the National Piping Centre, the city overlaid with the skirl of the pipes.How the pipes came to Scotland is a bit of a puzzle. Some historians believe they originated in Egypt, before coming over with invading Roman Legions. Others claim they came across the Irish Sea with colonising Scots tribes.As early as  BC, the ldquopipes of Thebes were played in Ancient Egypt. These seemed to involve some blowing into hollow pipes made of dog skin with chanters of bone. A few centuries later, Emperor Nero is also believed to be a keen piper, so he was probably blowing, rather than fiddling, as Rome burned. Whoever invented them, we owned them. The original Highland pipes probably had a single drone, with a second drone added in the mid-s and the third, the great dronecame into use some time in the early s.At the time Lowland pipers were travelling minstrels, performing at feasts and fairs throughout the Borders. Highland pipers, on the other hand, held a loftier and more austere position within the clan system. By the late s, the pipes had replaced the harp, as the guitar would do later to just about every instrument.The first recorded entrance of the pipes as an instrument of war was in the last full-scale battle against the English which, closer to home, also involved religion. It was the Battle of Pinkie, which took place outside Musselburgh in , when the Scots army was defeated, aided by the guns of  English warships anchored in the Forth which decimated their ranks.It was a crucial turn in what was to became known the War of Rough Wooing. After breaking from Rome and Catholic Europe, an isolated King Henry VIII had wanted his son, Prince Edward, to marry the young Scottish Queen Mary and united two kingdoms. When Henry died and the boy became King Edward VI, his uncle, the Duke of Somerset, became Lord Protector of England and pursued the idea of an alliance ndash wanted or not ndash with the Scots, who still clung to the papacy. When the Scots battlelines crumbled there was no mercy and it is estimated that around , Scottish soldiers perished. Mary was smuggled out of Scotland and,  years later, married Francis, Dauphin of France.Due to their inspirational influence the pipes were classied as an instrument of war and banned for a time after the Battle of Culloden in . There has barely been a war, a battle or skirmish since that hasnrsquot involved a band, or piper, particularly as the British Empire expanded and Scottish soldiers, and pipers led regiments into battles in foreign fields.One of the most famous and oldest pipe tunes, the Green Hills of Tyrol, dates to the Crimean War when a pipe major with the rd Sutherland Highlanders heard a Sardinian band playing what was a refrain from Rossinirsquos William Tell. He adapted it for the pipes.Many years later Andy Stewart, never seen without a kilt, would put the words to what became A Scottish Soldier. The song, recorded at Abbey Road, was one of two US chart entries by Stewart , reached number one in Canada, spent  weeks in the UK singles chart and over a year in the US chart. It was also huge in countries with a Scottish expatriate population, like Australia and New Zealand.This weekrsquos Piping Live! events have the National Piping Centre as their hub. In Edinburgh, therersquos a Fringe event tonight at St Ceciliarsquos Hall with The Piobaireachd Society putting on a concert of classical pipe music.Tomorrow at the Glasgow centre itrsquos the solo piping competition and at lunchtime, and throughout the week, bands will be on the steps of the Royal Concert Hall, Fiveways at TGI Fridays and at St Enoch Square. Therersquos also heat on of Pipe Idol, the under- solo competition.All the grade on bands will compete twice each day, performing three traditional types of tune ndash a march, a Strathspey and a reel ndash and a medley. The bands have to perform in a circle, facing inwards, assessed by four judges, two piping, one for drummers and a fourth for overall performance. Therersquos also a drum major competition, the massed march past The Worldsrsquo Chieftain, culminating in every piper on the Green thousands playing in unison, a sound which should certainly reach the parts of Glasgow that the previous week has not touched.For a full breakdown of whatrsquos on go to www.pipinglive

title: gold-rush-commercial-goldmine-set-running-december
story: But gold-mining is about to become a reality for a firm in Tyndrum, Argyll, after it received the necessary funding to buy the excavation equipment needed to start work at the site.Scotgold Resources has been working to reopen an abandoned gold mine in Cononish for  years and claims it will now be able to begin commercial gold production later this year.If successful, this will be the first time in decades that the precious metal has been mined in Scotland.Richard Gray, managing director and CEO at Scotgold, said he believes the the project will ldquoprovide a signicant boost to the local economy around Tyndrum.In the latest raft of funding for the firm, finance provider Simply has loaned the project pound,, which has been used to purchase equipment including an excavator, a loading shovel and a dumper.It is hoped that this will give the firm the last push it needs to be fully operational by the end of the year.Ross Pickburn, regional sales manager at Simply, said: ldquoThis was an incredibly interesting deal to work on, not least because it was the first gold mine Irsquod ever helped fund.ldquoItrsquos great working with a company that produces Scottish gold and a team that is creating jobs in the area.ldquoWe got to know about the needs of the company and were able to structure a deal that worked for all parties.Scotgold acquired the Cononish site in  and has embarked on a long journey to bring the mine up to a workable state and start producing gold.Planning permission for the project has been agreed, subject to certain conditions, by Loch Lomond and Trossachs National Park Authority, while the business also recently renegotiated and extended a secured loan deal with Nat le Roux, its chairman and ldquomajor shareholder.The loan facility from Mr le Roux, who is a former chief executive of the IG Group, is said to have increased by up to poundm to poundm.At one point Scotgold predicted that gold and silver production at the site could reach as much as pound million per year over a seven-year lespan.However, this has changed over time due to fluctuations in the price of gold.Experts think there could be as much as five tonnes of gold to be found in the hills near Tyndrum, encased in quartz which must be dug out and crushed.Up to , ounces of precious metals could be mined per year, and the project could create around  jobs for local people.Villagers in nearby Tyndrum, a popular stop on the route north to Glencoe and Fort William, hope to open a visitors centre and market Cononish gold to tourists.Scotgold produced its first gold from Cononish several years ago during a bulk ore processing trial at the site.It was later sold for an average of pound, per ounce, a more than three-fold premium on the average gold price of the day.The mineral was sold in the form of ldquorounds minted by Baird and Co Bullion Merchants.The first round, embossed, like all the coins, with a stagrsquos head, was snapped up by Graham Donaldson, a Scotgold shareholder who lives in Christchurch, Dorset.His bid of pound,.p was the highest.At the time of the sale, he said: ldquoAs to what I would do with it now, I would probably look at it and stroke it, and put it in a safe.Mr Donaldson said he and his we planned in time to get new engagement and wedding rings made from Cononish gold, to replace the budget rings they bought when they married.ldquoThose are worn thin, he added.Scotgold, which also has offices in West Perth, Australia, believes its gold will attract a premium price as a niche product for tourists, jewellers and couples keen on Scottish gold wedding or engagement rings.The firm also previously announced it had struck a deal with a prominent jeweller to manufacture the first items made from Scottish gold.Exploration work in another area - the Grampian gold project - is also continuing, with a view to potentially developing sites in the Ochils, Glen Orchy, Glen Lyon, Inverliever and Knapdale under Crown Estate ldquooption agreements.

title: bothies-get-21st-century-makeover
story: Created in the main from estate buildings built for stalking parties or gamkeepers, bothies provide basic but generally wind and watertight accommodation in remote locations which are left unlocked for anyone to use and have become popular with hillwalkers and climbers.Scattered throughout the wilder parts of Scotland, England and Wales they are the shepherdsrsquo cottages, huts and similar buildings many of which in the normal course of events might be allowed to fall derelict.Very few are less than a century old and the ravages of time, climate and remoteness makes maintenance a challenge.Now it has emerged that in a bid to make them fit for the st century, a record amount has been spent to get them into shape.Repairs and updates to the tune of pound, have been made over a year to continue to offer a safe place for climbers out in the mountains.The Mountain Bothy Association was founded  years ago by Bernard Heath after he spotted a remark in the visitor book at the Backhill of the Bush bothy in Galloway Forest park, suggesting the setting up of a club to save a growing number of deserted farm buildings from ruin.He felt a collective effort was needed to keep the abandoned cottages and huts weatherproof in order ldquoto maintain simple shelters in remote country for the use and benefit of all who love wild and lonely places.The charity now runs over  bothies across the UK with the vast majority being in Scotland. They obtain the ownersrsquo permission to maintain buildings as bothies and to make them available as open shelters.MBA volunteers are tasked with visiting the buildings to look for any structural faults or cosmetic issues that need fixing or more fundamental renovation. And it is the volunteers that carry out the restoration and maintenance work which is financed by member subscriptions and by donations.The charity revealed that their latest annual spending on the bothies has risen by % and expect that the expenditure will not stop there.Neil Stewart of the MBA said: "We now look after  bothies plus two emergency mountain shelters throughout Scotland, Wales and northern England."Through membership fees and generous donations we managed to spend a record sum of pound, on bothy maintenance in  and managed to increase our membership to over , - an increase of %."These buildings are however in remote areas and subject to the worst ravages of the weather so ongoing repair and maintenance is required. We look forward to continuing our efforts in years to come to provide open shelters in remote country for use by outdoor enthusiasts."Its biggest task in  was taking over the Garbh Choire refuge hut deep in the Cairngorms National Park and doing extensive work to bring it into use as part of the scheme.Among the projects was a former schoolhouse at Duag Bridge in the northern Highlands, which had declined to a state of dereliction, which was taken on as a new bothy by the association and fully renovated.Camban bothy in the western Highlands, which has been an MBA-maintained building for  years, was given another major renovation with volunteers undertaking work over a number of weeks.Concerns over bats delayed progress in getting Willrsquos Bothy in working order in southern Scotland, but the MBA say they still hope to have work completed this year.In its latest annual report for  the trustees of the MBA said: "The Association believes it has a duty to care for the quality of the experience enjoyed by those who visit bothies, and to ensure that all those who are involved in outdoor recreation understand the fragile nature of this resource, and the impact their behaviour can have on the bothy and its environment."In general, the work of the association continues to be a success. We are achieving our objective in maintaining simple shelters in remote country for the use and benefit of all who love wild and lonely places."A bothy would not normally be connected to the public utilities, and any amenities provided would be of a very basic standard.In areas there is an appreciable fire hazard, or limited fuel, existing fireplaces may be replaced by a stove.The increase in spending comes a month after a bid was being being made to stamp out antisocial behaviour, vandalism and fire-raising at remote bothies in southern Scotland.Police said they wanted to ensure the shelters were "used for the purpose they are intended for".In one recent incident a group of hillwalkers was denied access by a "bothy full of revellers" and later had to be rescued off a hillside.Bothy Watch aims to raise awareness and keep the buildings free from damage.A wide range of groups including Forestry and Land Scotland, the Mountain Bothies Association , local authorities and mountain rescue team volunteers are involved in the initiative.
